headline: Worse job ever
pros:
Getting to go home and finally leaving
If you want to loose weight work there
cons:
No safety wear issued your dragging out pallets with no safety boots, no googles when using bailer to protect eyes, no proper thick freezer gloves so would get freezer burn on your hands there was a shortage of gloves to wear when putting out stock so I was using gloves from previous employment some staff had paid for their own. Long hours you would be expected to stay over to get stock worked if the day was busy could be 12.30pm or even 4 and 5am then still be expected to do your shift the following day. Heavy work expected to work pallets with unrealistic times a bread pallet would have to be worked is less than 9 mins and 15 mins for the heavier pallets, as a manager you are constantly running around doing the heavy work load while staff are on the tills, micro managed the worse Iv ever experienced assistant store manager constantly on your back, sitting in the office watching staff on cctv then dragging them out the break room on the dot of their break finishing, standing at the tills watching how long it takes for staff to get off the till once’s they have finished with customers, no duty of care to staff, no return to work being done, if you injury yourself your doing your own first aid and no ones recording accidents.
You can’t plan your life as rot-as aren’t done in advance.
No safe and legal standards managers giving keys to under age staff to authorise alcohol sales without then having to come and do it.
Some staff are paid more than the deputy store managers too

headline: Total lack of support and they will work you to the bone
pros: Salary, great benefits, area manager job good (its just getting there)
cons:
60+ hour weeks - shift patterns change during your store training time, be prepared for some shifts with a 5am or earlier start and some shifts with a 10pm finish. All in the same week. 

No work/life balance - you do not get two consecutive days off in my experience, any time you come home the management have put such a large amount of pressure on you that you end up worrying at home, or sleeping because your sleep pattern is so up and down - expect some nights with 5hrs sleep. 

Unfair expectations - in the job during store manager time you are expected to anticipate things that are way beyond your experience. When you get to the grading period, you are left to sink or swim regardless of whether you have experienced something before. 

Mentors - this is a very poor description of what Aldi provide. These "mentors" are the people that critically evaluate your performance. They are given assessor roles which means that there is no where to turn to in the organisation if you are having issues without it being marked against you.

headline: If you value your mental health (and you should) DO NOT work here.
pros: 40% discount and office environment. Good food, beauty treatment and gym (in a non Covid world)
cons: Where do I begin. Everything was wrong from the start. They were not geared up to welcome new starters and I waited 8 weeks for the systems access in order to do my job properly. I then waited a further 4 weeks for my line manager to hand over jobs to me because they are the worst micro managers and don’t know how to delegate or manage their time. On top of that the blame culture within ASOS is the worst I have ever experienced, no one is accountable for anything with a lot of people looking to hide mistakes, blame someone else and talk down to you. I have spent the last 5 months being gaslighted by my boss who is incompetent and thrives off making people feel bad about themselves. The systems at ASOS are not fit for purpose and you spend 80% of your time waiting for reports to run/information to come back and even then you have to run 3 reports because the reporting system can’t handle the amount of lines you’re reporting on. The whole set up is a waste of people’s time and skills. I am fortunate enough to have never suffered from my mental health prior to working here but the way I have been treated at ASOS means I have suffered from the worst anxiety and panic attacks ever. There hasn’t been a day I haven’t cried or been treated poorly and the job isn’t worth it, the workload and the pay is the worst. Don’t put yourself through it. They email on sundays and at 9pm + and it is not conducive to good work life balance or a happy lifeX

Opportunities are there if you know where/who to ask. People help people so make sure you speak to the people you have a good working relationship with about what you want from your career. I've worked across three offices in my two-years at Amey thus far and have always found staff friendly.

headline: Say what you mean, mean what you say
pros:
Anglian Water is a forward thinking, change delivering, frontier pushing company that recognizes and respects that it's people are it's most important and valuable asset.
The values of Anglian Water and all of the normal company slogans actually feel like they mean something, and people here really do feel part of a bigger purpose.
I am well supported by my immediate managers and others across the business are always willing to help and share their knowledge. I am also well rewarded, particularly for the region we work in.
The additional benefits available to employees, annual leave, medical cover, mental health and financial support are exceptional.
cons:
As a regulated business, reward (whilst fair) is lower than similar roles in truly private sectors (but more secure).
There are some really big challenges facing the water industry, if you aren't passionate about change and progress - the hard work needed over coming years will be a negative.

headline: Good lifestyle bad money
pros: Good lifestyle, always out and about in the van and quite an easy life. The blokes are good to work with. Most managers are really good and willing to do a lot to help you where they can and there is room to move around in the company if you so choose. If your not looking to make a lot of money and prefer a more chilled out approach to life this will really suit you
cons: Shared bad moral when I left due to cutting back of costs. Over time is the only way to make a good wage however is being cut back. If your living in an area where cost of living is high you may want to do some accounts to see if you can afford it if your used to living on a larger wage. The same pay scale is used in the south as is used in the north so depending what the cost of living is it could however be more appealing. Seams like a lot of issues are also not always passed up the chain of command to higher up managers which means they quite often do not know the issues they need to address and there are 1 or 2 managers dotted around that can be a bit of a jobs worth, most are lovely people though

headline: Please just take a second and read this.
pros:
The cafe in the main building is very nice and has a wide variety.
Electrical outlets to charge electric cars are in the garages.
cons: The political nonsense is more than enough to drive someone into a deep depression. I have worked in the industry for quite sometime. I have to say, AstraZeneca was by far the worst place I have ever been employed at. There was a new hire orientation every single Monday for full time people and new contractors. Meaning their turn over rate is just awful. I know several women who worked their for 6+ years, that were let go. Yet they are still hiring. They also promise all of their contractor that once they are full time their pay will increase, but it doesn’t. Instead, they will keep that person a contractor for as long as they can, then cut their contract. I have seen it happen with every single contract person I knew. Higher ups are extremely hypocritical due to the fact that they spout these values saying that they care about diversity and inclusion. All the while locally they tried and tried denying any group that has to do with the LGBTQ+ community. There is also a major racial and sexist issues. When a complaint of racism or sexism would be reported, higher ups would look the other way. Even if HR got involved, they know these people so instead of taking a reasonable action against numerous complaints, instead, they force the victim out of the company. Not the perpetrator! They would put the victim on PIP for no reason, they would pull work from other teams only to increasing the vics workload. If they email for time off months in advance higher ups will flat out deny it. I also attempted to move to several better positions. I went through all of the processes and even got verbal offer letters. However when the time came for the actual offer letters, I never heard anything. I never even got rejection emails. Instead, I would just meet the person they put into the position. Those people are truly monsters and they still work there to this day. Please please please whatever you do, if you are thinking about working here, think twice. If you are through the hiring process, get hired and find something else. Keep your head down and do not fully engage with anyone. The moment that you do, they will find something about you that they do not like and your job will be on the line. I sincerely kid you not.

headline: Fantastic Company
pros:
I have thoroughly enjoyed working for the company for almost 10 years now; 8 of which as a Store manager.

I began my career as a Christmas temporary colleague on a 16hour contract and progressed quickly due to the opportunities and development that B&M offered. 

Within this time I have worked at five stores; ranging from a B&M Bargains store to a B&M Homestores with a garden centre and freezers.

I can honestly say that all of the people who I’ve met during my career whom work for B&M, on all levels, are absolutely brilliant. 

The people are what make this business so special and every store that I have worked in has had a “Family” feeling to it, whereby the teams have all work tremendously hard to deliver the high standards expected by the business for its customers. 

It’s a very exciting, fast paced retailing environment to work within that’s both rewarding and enjoyable.

If your hardworking, dynamic as well as able to be creative whilst following process and procedure you will love working for this Company.

I am extremely grateful for the training, development and opportunities that B&M has given to me as an employee and would highly recommend this Company to anyone who’s interested in making a Career with a Retailer that offers job security.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about this Secure, Growing Company.

headline: The best 2 years of my Career so far!
pros:
Since joining the company 2 years ago, I have been on an amazing journey of development and success. The company is ambitious, it is thriving and it is well placed to succeed for many years to come.
We are encouraged to trade our stores, take ownership and accountability and we are trusted to lead our teams.
There is many opportunities to develop and progress upwards if you want, and if you do - the support network and encouragement is amazing. I have never felt so supported and pushed to be the very best I can be, and I have been stretched and nurtured over the last 2 years whilst being given many opportunities to further my career.
The culture in the company is really positive, and we have really helped to provide a crucial offering to the country in this incredibly difficult year. The company have supported us immensely and given us all the tools possible to continue to serve the nation.
cons:
As with all retail roles, the nature of the industry involves working many weekends.
The renumeration package could certainly be improved.

headline: Treated like trash but pay is good
pros: The only reason is for the money. BAT used to care about its employees but not anymore.
cons:
Let's start with the basics, is a shrinking company that promises to increase dividends every year no matter the cost.
The solution identified is very simple: cost reduction.
- Every year there is a project called Quantum that puts you at notice so you can apply for your own position, this generates a terrible atmosphere.
- Apart from that, roles are being moved overseas on a daily basis.
- Now BAT is suspending salary adjustments even with an amazing year in order to profiteering from the COVID situation.
- For those who remain, the workload is insane and you are expected to work 12 hours a day in order to achieve the targets set
- High-level management now uses very low-level tactics that if you don't deliver unachievable targets you will be part of the next wave of redundancies.
- Next point is the complete lack of planning before these role movements, it is kind of normal to have employees leaving the company and then a consulting firm doing the same job but at a higher price, just for the management of the area show he was able to reduce some number of FTEs even if spending more money.
- If you are coming from abroad, make sure to include a stabilization clause on your contract. I saw too many times people moving from other countries to the UK on a working visa just to be made redundant 1 after, even with very good performance ratings.
- Finally, in an act to spit in the face of employees and show how committed to cost reductions the company is, the CEO switched his company car from a BMW to a Bentley.

- Back to back meetings during the day and having to do the ACTUAL work that I'm supposed to do during my evenings, weekends and non-existent spare time. No work-life balance.
- The vaping division announced a 52% rise in profits and then not even a week later the company announced the biggest wave of cuts the company has seen in years. Really tells you something about how much the company values its staff. The senior management is determined to keep showing an increase in profits at the expense of laying off people and cutting resources. In other words, they are in lights switching off mode it seems.
- Extremely disorganised processes. Nobody on the team actually understands the fundamental step by step processes needed to execute a project. It's frankly alarming. There is really no proper structure anywhere (at least in the vaping division)
- POINTLESS Bureaucracy. Why do we need all these stupid meaningless forms that need to be filled out every step of the project? Why do we need to have so many alignment and pre-alignment meetings? WHY?!
- The guys at the top are very clearly an old boy's club.
-Lots of sucking up in meetings to senior management. Gross to watch. 
-Proper good old fashioned corporate machine.

headline: The world champions of botched SAP implementations
pros: None that I could list.
cons:
While the rest of the company manages its operations on a shoestring, the IT department still believes that "BAT has too much money"; that standpoint drives the whole department behaviour in terms of performance, culture and integrity.

Regarding performance, the vast majority of IT projects fail miserably. When I was working in that department, the joke was that BAT were the world champions of failed SAP projects. The reason is, failure is not seen as an issue in that department, confidence and arrogance are valued much more than competence. And, of course, your ethnicity: woe be to those outside of "CANZUK" + (white) South Africa.

As a result, the culture is based on blaming others for one's own failures, and hijacking your neighbour's successes. People at the top are low-level technicians whose only skill is to relish in abject subservience to their superiors, unable to see the big picture while convinced they are "leaders". Bullies flourish within BAT IT department, and attain the highest positions.

And, as "BAT has too much money", the way vendors are selected and managed is particularly worrying. Again, they are not selected with the business' interests in mind. More expensive, less performing vendors are preferred over more efficient and cheaper ones, even when the choice implies a huge risk to operations. Or useless technologies are purchased to allow the IT "architects" to garner their resumes with that specific skill. Sometimes vendors are selected based on the "cultural fit", meaning the nationality of the vendor - pure Brexit style.

If you have any principle or talent, avoid at all cost.

headline: Good environment, challenging work, space to shine
pros:
- Great People: Employees are smart, helpful and caring. I've worked closely with many colleagues in different squads and tribes, and really enjoyed working with everyone. There's a strong focus on sharing knowledge and enabling people's voices to be heard.

- Large impact: We're continuing to grow our user-base at a high rate, which means your work helps a large number of people. The experience of real users is generally very positive.

- Career Advancement: Many of my colleagues have been promoted, with some gaining more leadership roles. There is a renewed focus on recognizing employees performance, and the on-going changes to the review process give me confidence this will continue.

- Compensation: Salary for London Engineering is solid, even better when the stock scheme is included. I can't speak for other areas of the business.
cons:
- Shifting Team Structures: I have been through at least 3 major re-orgs. These are preceded by lack of clarity on objectives, and followed by lack of cohesion between the resulting teams. As a company scales this will happen, but we need to be more careful when and how this is done.

- Shifting Focus: Some areas of the business have become slowly neglected over time, either through technology change (i.e. mobile) or due to leaders leaving and not being replaced. Lack of domain knowledge and lack of support will hurt us in the future.

headline: 1 star, would not recommend
pros: Fast-paced, there are a lot of hard workers and most are generally friendly and willing to help. As an employee, you are encouraged to be self-motivated and will learn a lot.
cons:
There is no clear strategy, onboarding, or management for employees. For a healthcare tech company, an employee's healthcare experience is often overlooked, unappreciated, and at times even unwanted. Everyone's moving so fast to tackle the next fire that it often feels like the company is like a dog running around in circles chasing its own tail. A lot of energy and effort are placed on creating fancy presentations bragging about the app and our global reach but the follow through and overall direction is missing. During my time with Babylon, we experienced dozens of firings which left employees on edge wondering if they were on the chopping block next this resulted in a lot of people just keeping their heads down to maintain their jobs. 

There was also a tug of war between the US and UK leadership and constant reorgs of teams which added to the confusion and it was obvious that the overall "why" was not understood across the company. There have been efforts made to improve the culture for the US team but in general morale is low.

headline: Only getting worse
pros:
The associates and shift leads within the Clinical Operations team are supportive to one another in spite of the obvious distancing of the management team (team leads + senior associates). 
the company has a lot of potential in the right hands.
cons:
all levels of the the Clinical Operations team are prone to frequent burnouts due to:
1. inefficient management
2. increasing appointment numbers without fixing backlog first
3. general feelings of being unsupported 

there are clear conflicts of interest if you ever want to go to the HR team about the management team, as they protect their friendships with each other rather than the experience of employees. 

management has a frequent bad habit of calling sudden and urgent meetings to the whole team without any context, causing associates unnecessary stress, and often make insinuations that there is someone to blame in those meetings. one may also find themselves not receiving any negative feedback until they are called into a private meeting with their senior associate, in which another member of management will actually be there to tell you that you're doing a bad job. 

changes to internal clinical processes or employee policies are always framed as "improvements" when in fact they are detrimental to patient care in terms of workload or makes having a work-life balance even more difficult. 

they even say that they "care about your mental health" and yet when you tell them about your issues, they tell you to take advantage of the free counselling sessions (which book up almost immediately from all the depressed/anxious employees) or make you jump through hoops of trying to get accommodations to the point where you give up and they say "okay let us know if there's anything we can do to support you :) ". 

They advertise that there are growth opportunities, but you have to have been in your position for at least 6 months before being considered as an applicant for a promotion. Even then, they may often hire externally for higher up positions citing "business needs" rather than valuing their employees' professional growth. 

you get 20 days of vacation BUT you can only use them at a certain time, ie. you cannot go on vacation during the summer or the winter holidays or anytime that people usually take vacations, OH and you're not allowed to carry over your unused vacation days to the following year. so you probably have to take your vacation during September/October/November. 

there is so much wrong with the company from an employee standpoint. they exploit their employees and gaslight you into thinking you're doing it "to help all Canadians have access to healthcare". the irony is that they push their employees to start using healthcare for the anxiety and other mental health issues they cause.

headline: Driven by profits, defensive to feedback, lack of accountability
pros:
- get to work with some great people
- opportunity to get an "inside" look at the emerging field of Telehealth
- gain experience working in fast-paced "start-up" environment (could be a con for some people)
- offers benefits and 4 weeks vacation and competitive wage for entry-level position
cons:
- Technology is lacking and not adapted well to the Canadian health care system leading to inefficient processes and delayed delivery of care to patients.
- Scaling and expansion continue at rapid rate rather than focusing on improving and fixing the technology, leading to an increase in workload at the expense of employees and patients.
- Despite repeated feedback from employees, management often gives the message that "it is what it is" or "we're working on it" but offers little reassurance or transparency in terms of actions being taken to address concerns. Feedback is sometimes met with defensiveness instead of acknowledgment. The company's response to the other Glassdoor review is a good example of how concerns are not really fully addressed.
- Management promotes the message that working hard and taking on extra tasks will lead to further opportunities but when it comes to giving actual promotions, the hiring team is quick to tell you that the credentials listed on your resume (i.e. external experience) are what it takes to "meet the company needs" rather than proven internal experience and performance. Moving up in this company can feel like a moving target to those hoping to grow their career at Babylon and leaves hard-working employees feeling used.
- Solutions to tackle high workload and backlog of patient care related tasks put forth by management often involve increased monitoring rather than steps to address employee stress/burnout and patient safety, ultimately leading to further stress and a feeling of not being valued as individual employees.
- Many (entry-level) employees feel overworked, under-appreciated and their feedback discounted. Management tries to address these concerns with occasional words of appreciation/encouragement but it has come to a point where employees need to see real action and not empty words.
***Most importantly, acts of workplace racism, harassment, and bullying are not met with proper action. Rather than applying company policy, professionalism, and proper research on reducing harm to victims and increasing workplace safety, they have deflected blame and allowed personal relationships to bias their decision-making in these matters. They have not taken appropriate steps to ensure victims and witnesses of workplace bullying and harassment feel safe at work and have also not taken steps to ensure such behaviors will not happen again, resulting in severe negative impact to those affected.

headline: The C in CEO is for Chaos.
pros:
- Top-class design team. It's a shame that some good people have left or are leaving.
- Great salary.
cons:
- The mission is a lie - Babylon focuses on delivering tech products to big health org (mostly Insurance providers) with the aim to reduce costs to THEM. But it's up to these orgs to reduce their cost to the end-user. Where is the data that shows that we are closer to achieve our mission?
- Senior leadership has no experience with tech - The CEO and other people in C-Suite has no experience with tech or managing product organisations. Their decisions are random and dictatorial creating a chaotic environment.
- There is never time to build the right thing - The business is led by the commercial team and all their short-sighted deals. They decide what goes to product roadmaps. Product teams then need to work in a rush to make sense of the commercial deal and try to build a solution that either meets the user needs or the partner needs. What do you think a CEO who is ex-Goldman Sachs is going to prioritise?
- Design Leaders mysteriously disappear - Product Directors, Heads of Design and Chief Design Officers get fired after doing something that contradicts senior leadership. 
- Poor culture - Long and stressful hours. We say that 1 day at Babylon feels like 1 week, and 1 week feels like 1 month, and 1 month feels like a year. If you care about your mental health, look for somewhere else.
- Lack of transparency - No transparency from Senior Leadership or leadership on what decisions have been made and why.
- No salary review process, career progression and no incentives.

headline: The next Theranos/WeWork?
pros: There are kind, smart and hardworking people here, but they are like frogs in a slow boiling pot of water and cannot see how bad this working environment has become.
cons: I left Babylon after less than a year because I couldn't stand the insane and toxic work environment for under market pay and benefits. For context, I have never worked at a company for less than 5 years... My last company was a very successful start-up, so I can handle a disorganized org that needs people to roll up their sleeves and do the hard work. This was anything but a good challenge. The benefits are basically nonexistent. There is no bonus program, so your salary is the only comp you will get for the year and there is no additional compensation for top performers. There is also no formal review process so the only way you can get a raise is threaten to quit unless they pay you more. Their health care benefits are so expensive ($2k/month for a small family) that many employees opted to be uninsured. The company has no vision or business strategy. Many of the people who run the company have nepotistic relationships with the CEO (family members, former coworkers, former nanny for his children!). They are overpaid and under-qualified. This company is the most political and toxic place I have ever worked. I was being actively bullied by a VP. She spent working hours scheduling 1:1s with colleagues with the sole intent to badmouth me. When these colleagues came to me to report these incidents, because she was saying such atrocious things about me that they were made uncomfortable, I reported it to HR and they did next to nothing. Why? Because this person has a close personal relationship with the CEO. What was my crime? Who knows! I wanted post mortems when launches failed (and every single one did!). That was somehow seen as a personal attack and resulted in a vendetta. The CEO is actively looking for an exit event and therefore does not care about improving anything within the organization. He even knew about my bully incidents (because my manager told him) and he did nothing. There is also a total lack of transparency. Babylon lost valuation during the time I was employed there and no one said a word. Not to mention, the contracts we have with clients are leaving us bleeding cash in every state we launch in. Almost none of them are profitable or have a path to profitability. There is also bound to be some catastrophic regulatory or compliance incident here as there is no clinical oversight. Want to schedule back-to-back consults with a clinician to drug shop and get the same prescription from multiple doctors? You can absolutely do that, because there is nothing before, during, or after the consult to stop you. Want a Schedule II drug? The clinicians aren't supposed to prescribe these, but there is nothing to stop them. If Babylon was bigger in the US, TechCrunch or another tech publication would tear this place apart as it's on track to be the next Theranos or WeWork. I have never been happier than the day I gave my notice and I will look back on this time as part of the dark cloud that was 2020.

headline: Window dressing and lip service
pros: You will absolutely be challenged as the mission is a big and complex one. Peers and “doers” in the company are some of the best and brightest I’ve ever worked with, although those talented people are now choosing to leave in their droves to find a place where they will be better appreciated.
cons:
There is a complete disconnect between the teams in commercial, product and engineering resulting in constant internal bickering and “retros” that never see the light of day after they’ve been churned out. They serve no purpose other than to provide fodder for the inevitable witch hunt to identify the “guilty” party in whatever is the latest drama.
The highest turnover of management I’ve ever seen coupled with perpetual re-orgs and inability to stick with any form of strategic direction for longer than a few months has resulted in an organisation pushing and pulling in different, and mostly opposing, directions.
The above, plus many other reasons, results in the constant feeling of having a target on ones back and the thought that anyone will be discarded when they have burnt out and served their purpose.
I am truly sad that I’m writing this as I had high hopes for the company and my place within it. My, and l’m sure many of my colleagues, main reason for sticking it out is the promise of shares, although they appear to be decreasing in their value with each passing day.

headline: Well-intentioned people but dysfunctional
pros:
- Lovely, smart people 
- Great for juniors
- Free Babylon consultations
- New C-suite seems promising
- Rumour has it an IPO is coming in next few months so it may improve in 3-4 years time
- I’ll reiterate - the people I worked with are so nice and not aggressive at all. Pleasant environment
cons:
- Pay and benefits suck. They say they’ve done benchmarking BUT they group all sort of functions in the same band (for example, a software engineer and a customer support agent could be on the same band). The benefits are not on par with tech companies. 
- In fact, this is not a tech company. It’s a healthcare company 
- No pay rises in over two years
- Skeptical about alleged bonus
- Not giving shares to new joiners 
- Highly dysfunctional. Few things work properly, especially in the realm of HR processes and communication. Many departments leave a lot to be desired 
- Way too many directors; most of them are too inexperienced and would probably not be directors in other companies 
- Bad career progression. They make it extremely difficult (you have to interview for a promotion)
- Complete switch in strategy - 99% of the effort now goes into selling to insurance companies in the US, but the healthcare and product behind the commercial offering is not up to par
- I was quite bored. Many people say they’re at 20%-50% capacity and some others love their work, so I think this may be personal
- Many leavers
- Little delegation of decision-making from the top

headline: Lack of leadership ruined a great opportunity

Instead it was constant change of direction, a constant rebranding of half finished mistake riddled work, that ultimately left everyone I knew who worked there jaded and unsatisfied. Couple that with fairly poor remuneration and a complete black box of HR and career progression it’s not hard to understand why everyone is leaving.

headline: Stay away if you’re US-based
pros: There are a couple of amazing souls that also work at Babylon. Shared suffering is often cathartic.
cons:
1. The CEO is a poor leader and fosters a toxic work culture that trickles down through each department. For a company that wants to help people this CEO expresses little care for people. Example: He disrespects his own team and cuts them off on all-hands meetings. 
2. Over the last few years they have delayed and misrepresented equity compensation to incoming new hires. Many US employees got together in 2019 and 2020 to compare equity promises vs awards and found many red flags, misrepresentations and continually changing language designed primarily to favor the company. If you politely ask about it or complain they respond with fiercely defensive legal language as if you’re going into a court battle - these types of responses stopped most employees from bringing it up at all. Several good people simply left the company over it.
3. Babylon is a U.K. centric company so don’t expect much career advancement or autonomy / authority if you‘re US-based.

headline: Getting less attractive by the minute
pros:
- The mission to bring affordable healthcare to people is, at the end of the day, one of the main benefits.
- Opportunity to work with some great people, although the good ones are leaving in droves for a long time now which has become very demoralizing.
- Opportunity to work on interesting projects in an interesting industry.
cons:
- Career progression is non-existent with both managers and HR to blame. HR constantly changes the framework every year and managers promote based on unfair criteria such as how friendly you are with them. Forget about salary increase, even for inflation, you will be served every fairy tale in the world to explain why that's not possible.
- The business changes directions every month or so which is not atypical for a startup, however, due to heavy regulations in the industry this makes everything move extremely slowly at ground level and you're stuck in a limbo state not being able to focus on actual work towards a goal.
- Benefits disappear suddenly such as the employee discount scheme, and engineers are provided with low specced laptops from three years ago to work on even though this is a unicorn.
- Heavy regulation impedes a lot of the engineering progress and results in a mess of useless processes to make a few people feel safe.

There is more and a great deal more has already been said in other reviews on the negative side, some bits exaggerated, some bits just not happening in my team, but at the moment the cons objectively outweigh the pros by a significant margin, otherwise there wouldn't be a big number of talented people jumping ship.

headline: The place to be!
pros: Everything you could ask for in a startup
cons: Prone to changing direction quickly

headline: Shoot for the stars and you will be given the opportunity
pros:
Challenging work, bleeding-edge tech which gives you lots of opportunity to grow. You have freedom to work on things that matter for you, and you can really contribute to the company mission - which is highly motivating.
The people here are amazing, everyone is very supportive of each other. And so smart! Lots to learn from each other and nobody ever looks down at someone.
Diversity is another important point - everyone is included, everyone is supported. Man, woman, non-binary, gay, queer, purple hair, any religion - everyone is welcome and treated like a member of the family.
cons: Chaotic - if that's not what you like, you won't feel comfortable here.

headline: The worst company I've ever worked for.  AVOID.
pros: None. Absolutely none. This company is clinically dangerous and scarily incompetent.
cons:
- Frequent patient confidentiality breaches which are not taken seriously
- Frequent clinical incidents due to delayed referrals, missing blood tests
- Clinics often not fit for purpose due to lack of equipment and lack of staff.
- Culture of shoulder rubbing and networking/getting drunk with management in order to rise up the ranks.
- Any highlighting of clinical breaches or concerns taken as clinician "not being a team player" and you are then excluded from the upper echelon clique.
- Blatant discriminatory behaviour towards people unable to attend social networking events.
- Bullying/clique culture
- Extremely poor communication with employees - bullying and abrupt emails
- Senior clinician team made up of highly privileged, privately educated corporate medical doctors who have no insight into the real world.

This list could go on for days. Essentially, if you are a doctor who has a strong sense of right and wrong and believes in equality in health care for all, then do not work for this corporate company. They do not care about you. They do not care about patients. They care about money, and that is all.

headline: The company has come through its growing pains as a fast-scaling start-up
pros:
Lots of brilliant people, both technically accomplished, interested in solving very hard problems and who genuinely care about the mission. 

There is lots of space for progression for most people. People management and processes in the company have come a long way in the last year to meet the standards you would expect from a mission-driven organization.
cons:
Both of these are getting better but:

There is a disconnect between the commercial and engineering sides of the business that result in misaligned priorities and frustration.

Some teams are much more functional and healthy than others.

pros: Fantastic learning opportunities in an amazingly talented and kind, driven design team. Mission you're working towards is overwhelmingly positive. The list can go on & on, in short, it's a place to run away from.

headline: Amazing Company to work with
pros:
One of the best companies I have seen, who provides such a good care to their employees, specially during COVID situation. They provide a flexible environment to work and support their employees in best possible ways. Some of the benefits that an employee get in Barclays are:
* Good Increment while joining the company (Don't forget to negotiate well)
* Flexible working environment
* Very good perks - free transportation; free tea, coffee and soups
* Annual Bonus (not included in your CTC)
* Encouragement for internal job movement. IJP policy is very good.
* Decent Annual Appraisal 
* No. of leaves are very good and there are many more.

During Covid, Barclays has extended enormous facilities to the employees, such as:
* Advance Salaries (which needs to be paid back in 6 months)
* Increment in the medical policies
* Additional Cash reimbursement for Covid treatment
*Free WFH kits that includes Ergonomics Chair, Monitor, Keyboard, Mouse, etc.
* Transportation for Covid treatment and Oxygen Supply
* A dedicated toll free for all Covid related queries, and many more.
cons: The only Con I found is that Barclays does not cover the Parents in the medical policies they enroll the employees. You have to pay the premium separately for your parents under VPA.

headline: Draconian micro monitoring if you are on the phones
pros: Overall I would say it’s a good company but your job satisfaction and enjoyment and stress levels are highly dependant on who your manager and ops leads are. Luckily most of my managers have been quite hands off with a laissez fair approach.

headline: ADSK IS THE WORST JOB EVER. This job and company are a joke. Avoid at all cost.
pros:
Amazing colleagues and people
Great overview of financial players
Decent - but not superb - corporate benefits (pension, art galleries access, healthcare)
It looks good on your CV if you're smart and are able to sell it well afterwards (and if you're lucky and your future employer hasn't already heard of this department)
Diversity and inclusion, lots of respect for culture/belief/sexual orientation/ideas, diversity is really promoted here, and this is fantastic.
It's a safe company to work at if you don't care about the meaning of your job, they will never fire you (unless you do something really bad)
cons:
First and foremost, the Analytics and Sales programme, is basically a call-centre. They will try and fancy it up as much as they can, and sell it to you..but it's essentially a customer service call centre, like that of a mobile phone carrier. okay? You will find yourself lying to yourself and telling your friends that you're an "aNaLyst iN FiNaNce" but you're simply a little replaceable tool in the decadent Bloomberg Terminal customer service support..
The company is obsessed with data and micromanagement, especially the Analytics (ADSK) department. They will drive you insane and push the limits of human respect and decency. They will be abusive to you. Read as many positive reviews as you want to convince you otherwise, you will still end up feeling this way or being in denial and paying the mental consequences later.
Micromanagement to the extreme, if you go to the toilet, there is a statistic for the time you left your desk and this will impact your salary review/bonus/progression. 
Lots of politics, if you play the game well you get away with it and succeed, if you're honest and don't cheat, you will never make it. Only smart cheaters win here, not the hard working people.
No work from home or other office flexibility, I almost lost my only ID once because Bloomberg wouldn't let me work ONE day from one of their offices in my Country of origin. At the same time they go on social media and brag about their network of offices and flexibility to explore regions and the world/rotational scheme...it's all a lie.
The company also promotes the idea of moving intra-department and growing your career and skills, they blocked me 3 times from moving department, they kept me captive in 2 different departments in the same way, and this is because all senior members of the team left and abandoned ship for something more decent than this "job".
Clients. Ohhh the clients. Clients verbally abuse you, everyday. EVERY. DAY. They shout at you on the phone, they insult you via the tickets on the customer service. They call you R word, they call you stupid. They threaten you. Have fun if you join.
Your schedule is pre-fixed, you have no power over it, you always have to be punctual and on time otherwise management will intimidate you and tell you off, yet if a ticket/client request/meeting overruns your lunch or your end of day, you have to lose your own time, and often lose lunch.
This was literally the worst experience in my whole career, many many colleagues lost their minds, some got depressed, some quit without a job, some believe in the corporate dream and are still lost in The Matrix and will end up staying in BBG for the rest of their lives with £2k increase every year, too tired and lazy to try move to a normal company.
Company culture is a joke. HR is a joke, their default reply is "sorry, this has to be discussed with your Team Leader”. But the TL have no power, rules always prevail.
Mike Bloomberg spends 500millions on Facebook ads for his hopeless presidential campaign and his company hits 11bn revenue, yet his firm pays offensively low salaries, low end of year increases, low bonuses, doesn't provide you with hardware to work from home with, no mid-year salary reviews (even if you change drastically role and seniority in April, you’re stuck on the same salary until March of the year after), sales doesn't get paid commissions!!

If you are ambitious don’t go there. The job is absolute nonsense. The team leads and the managers are there because they are not capable of doing actual jobs, so they find themselves in “managing” and micromanaging. For example, my team leader once was checking how I am sending an email to someone (not client). This job completely shattered my mental heath and self worth, I was so unhappy. And no, the problem was not me, since I left I am doing fine and don’t hate my job that much at any times despite any difficulties that I may have.

My advice to people who are stuck there and afraid to make a move: the earlier you do it the better for you. And no, free nuts are not a reason to keep a bad job. No one’s job should be as boring, annoying and self-humiliating.

headline: Used to be a great company, caring about people, but Covid showed their true colours
pros:
- Salary
- Decent health insurance (covers 90% of your expenses)
- Discount on your reservations up to 25%
- Tuition reimbursment up to 3000$/year
cons:
- Very few opportunities of evolution in the company
- Performance evaluations are in many cases quite unfair (the grid leaves a lot of room to interpretation) and it often turns to be a uncomfortable contest between managers...
- Big company with too many processes, everyone is in their "box", don't ask too many questions or they will blame you for not embracing change.
- They pretend to care about people but Covid showed many examples where there was no consideration whatsoever. Even though, we expected layoffs to happen, it was handled very poorly. 
Some typical examples such as : Demoting pregnant women (with lower pay of course, threatening them to take it or leave it), people who moved from a country to another for and with Booking suddenly stopped receiving any help with visa & immigration, therefore, we saw people who had 3 weeks to leave a country they were living in for 4+ years and nobody cared.
- More & more micromanagement
- They claim work/life balance is important but you still have to work 40+ hours a week with 50% travel
- Management in Canada is quite isolated from the rest of North America. the very few opportunities to evolve being mostly in the US and Booking won't help you for immigration there, so basically you are stuck where you are.

headline: Wouldn’t recommend
pros:
The employees were nice people to work with
The job itself was good
Opportunity to win good prizes on raffles and be gifted items as rewards
I was gifted items as a leaving present which was lovely
cons: I did a large amount of overtime whilst working for Boots and was paid incorrectly majority of the time which I advised the manager of most months and I had to wait until the following month to be paid the hours. At one point, all my unpaid accumulated to 40 hours and my manager told me they were going to have to pay me half this month and half the following month as it wasn’t in their budget to pay me it all in one month aka they were only allowed to spend a certain amount of funds on overtime each month. I declined this as they should pay any hours you are owed immediately however they still did this anyway and stated there was an error. One manager told me I might have to lose a weeks holiday as they didn’t have enough time to give it me, after seeking advise from Acas and advising them of this and that they weren’t legally able to do this, they immediately backtracked and gave me my holiday. I asked for a copy of my contract and was never given one. They wrote my hours of work down wrong one week which I told two managers about. When I finished at my correct time, I advised the Fire Marshall I was leaving and was confronted my the manager the next day for ‘leaving early’, he got quite confrontational to the point I was in tears and made a complaint to his manager. When I left, they unlawfully deducted £400 from my wages, something which happened a lot with other employees whilst I was working for Boots. When I queried this with a new manager they said they had checked with Payroll and it had been calculated correctly. I wrote a complaint to the regional manager who apologised and had a supervisor take over the issue who advised me Payroll had done it incorrectly and the new manager hadn’t even called Payroll.

pros:
It’s nice to speak to lots of different people. Sick pay after probation, and maternity pay after a year are better than what the government give you. 
The discount card is good but things that aren’t boots are generally cheaper elsewhere.

Managers are usually where they are as they’re massive suck ups, gladly they had a big cull lately, some are genuinely nice but they move on quick.
No development given for regular guys unless you beg and nag for it.
Customers can be rude and demand things and you’re expected to take it, they moan and get everything for free.
If someone gets Covid in your practice you’re expected to carry on as it’s ‘Covid secure’ though they don’t take the PPE rooms where you all change together or the staff rooms and back areas where everyone walks around without a mask talking, into account. Uniforms are horrible.
Optometrists can do whatever they want especially long serving ones and you’re supposed to pick up the abuse for them running late/putting in late holidays requests which are granted/having to rearrange the clinic due to the customers booking with the call centre who are awful and have no idea what they’re doing.
Rotas change constantly so you can’t plan anything, manager gets whatever they want and the rest cover them.

headline: Consider carefully before applying!
pros: There are opportunities to transfer or progress between Boots Opticians and main store. Offside training is provided and the package of benefits, including staff discounts, is generally very good.
cons: Do your research before applying or accepting a job offer. There is high staff turnover problem (see www.boots.jobs for the number of roles advertised) and the absence of a permanent manager in some stores, so if you are applying to work in a store with either or both of these issues, then you are likely to run into problems very quickly. Be under no illusion about working in optics. There is a lot to learn so it should not be seen as an easy option or a stop gap until something else comes along. Be mindful that the next patient who comes through the door may have a serious eye problem and possibly won’t know, and you may be the first person they encounter. Effectively, they and their eyes are in your hands.

headline: Overworked & Underpaid
pros:
I worked with a lovely team who had years of experience and very much enjoyed optics and the new things I was learning each day. There was good discounts on boots products and 70% off prescription glasses/sunglasses if you needed it. 
The sick leave and maternity pay was good. In general we had lots of good choices for frames and lens’ with customers. I really enjoyed the job when I first started as it felt like we really cared about people’s well-being.
cons:
Towards the end of my time here during the pandemic when they decided not to bring managers back into store, optical assistants were being overworked and underpaid; being expected to do a store managers job for zero pay increase this led to incredible stress and a day where my entire team cried because of how overwhelmed they was. 
Upper management were constantly making changes to the prices and procedures without consulting their staff on the ground which led to things that were not beneficial to the customer or the staff which clearly someone sat in an office who had no experience of optics had designed.

Lack of training meant there was many who could do one thing but not another and it led to a high turnover of staff as they felt inadequate when they couldn’t do things that they could if they had just had some training. 

The wage for the job you was doing was very small and actually one of the lower paying of opticians. No bonuses or commission made it feel as if it wasn’t worth it. 

The uniform was one of the worst things about the company, cheap polyester uniform that was constantly splitting or tearing and once it did break you could be waiting months before getting a new set. A customer once described it to me as looking militant and I couldn’t disagree with them. 

In my time there plenty of staff left but non were replaced which meant at times you had three people for three clinics and as soon as you had a walk in it meant everyone was rushing around without being able to give proper attention to the customer.

The rule of being stood up all day meant that we looked as if we was doing nothing when customers walked in when actually we had ten jobs in hand that we couldn’t deal with just so we looked as if we were ready to go for the next customer. 

If there is jobs going at any other opticians I would go there over boots, their work politics gets to be too much and you feel very inferior within the company; there is zero room for progression at most points but especially now as they are making staffing cuts.

headline: Like stepping back in time - in a bad way.
pros:
Senior leadership team are genuinely engaged and engaging. James Arrow (MD) and his team regularly holds video conference meetings with all practice managers, and doesn't shy away from answering difficult questions thoughtfully and meaningfully. Although the answers are usually, we can't afford to invest in that, it isn't a priority, or it's on the roadmap within the next five years (and has been for the last fifteen), the honesty is appreciated. 

Reasonable work life balance, although taking on more stores and more responsibility has changed that, it is still better than many other retail/optics management roles. Can switch off emails and ignore calls on holiday without repercussions, and little to no contact after normal business hours outside of genuine business emergency.
cons:
Very disordered, in the next couple of years Boots Opticians needs to either rapidly shape up, or they will be facing the end. Senior leadership do seem to know what their problem areas are, but seem unwilling or unable to face into them. 

Customers complain that we're too expensive and our prices are too confusing, so they reduced the price of some of the lenses, increased the price of others as well as most of the frames and added an extra tier into the pricing, making the end result more expensive and more confusing! 

Technology across the business is hugely out of date, we're still using paper records like it's 1993! The stock keeping system is ancient and unreliable, nobody (even loss experts) understands how it works. The PMS is a dangerously buggy mess that will bring up incorrect patient data, lose appointments and orders (literally every patient is has a duplicate file due to a mistake someone made about a year ago that nobody can work out how to fix!). The recall system was broken for around a year, with reminders sent randomly to the wrong patients and they either couldn't invest or couldn't work out how to fix it. The intranet is a broken joke where searching brings random results and half the links are broken. IT is outsourced as cheap as possible, so when issues come up (all the time), you are going to spend half an hour on hold, to some poor guy who speaks little to no English, and just needs to close the call as fast as possible regardless of if your issue is fixed or not. 
So the business obviously invests into online rota's that don't talk to the (outdated) payroll software and email accounts for OCs? Solving absolutely nobodies problems. 

Lack of critical maintenance points to a worrying cash flow problem in the business as a whole. Shops themselves, barring a few flagships, are uniformly shabby. Broken windows, leaking ceilings and damaged fixtures take months to be fixed, if at all. I've had parts of my store held together with duct tape for several months until maintenance can afford a fix. Critical testing kit is left out of commission, costing the business a fortune in lost revenue, for want of replacement parts. 

You're expected to deliver a premium product and service on a shoestring budget, with none of the tools or processes to deliver that. And when the half-baked processes inevitably fall down across the business, it isn't the fault of Nottingham where the processes were written, or the lack of investment has come from - it is individual practice managers and their teams who get it in the neck. 

Area management seems disordered and/or disinterested. Some good leaders are moved on or demoted, while others who seem utterly useless persist and are promoted beyond any logic.

The company has strong values that they truly live everyday in terms of doing the right thing for their clients and people. The people are smart yet humble, and truly care about each other. The culture is inclusive, fun and global. They offer amazing, best-in-class benefits and mobility options.
cons: While BCG has very competitive and generous salaries for consulting staff, they do not pay well for non-client facing roles such as HR, recruiting, marketing, finance, etc. There is a significant gap here in terms of years of experience for roles they are hiring for and what they are willing to pay; which often gets outweighed by the amazing benefits and flexibility they offer (especially by women who have or are trying to have a family).

headline: Software Engineer BCG Platinion: an incredible variety of clients and work, supported by a world class consulting firm
pros:
Being part of the engineering team at Platinion (a tech-focused unit of BCG) has been a great experience, and I have gotten to work with the best group of colleagues I've ever had. Each case / project has been a totally unique tech stack and problem to solve. Because we are a consulting firm, there is a good mix of heads-down coding and work along with client facing work. Platinion is often brought in by clients to build prototypes and MVPs for projects which makes the work faster paced and I think more fun. 
Platinion has a bit less intense style compared to the regular consultants at BCG, where there is pressure to be promoted or leave every 2 years.
We operate somewhat independently from BCG but still have all the perks and benefits of working at a top consulting firm. Perks that include the best health insurance ($5 copay for EVERYTHING), first class flights for flying, and incredible office spaces (the NYC office serves* breakfast and lunch every day with ample snacks and free Joe coffee throughout the day)

*going into the office and all office services are of course on pause for 2020 due to COVID
I trust our Platinion leadership and especially the BCG leadership; the BCG North America team I feel has done a great job handling the tumultuous year 2020

Consulting can feel rather isolating with traveling to clients and being on different teams all the time. BCG does a great job of recognizing this and making efforts for team and office events and culture. (They do a much better job at this than my former employer, a large IT consulting firm)

I'm not sure if this is available for Platinion but on the BCG side, when you are ready to leave or are told to leave, you are given a 3 full or 6 half months salary to seek your next position, as well as assistance from career services in your search.
cons:
The pace and workload can sometimes be high, but because cases have set end dates (usually at most a few months) there should always be a light at the end of the tunnel. 

From an engineer's standpoint, traveling every week to a client like a consultant felt like too much. But with COVID we're obviously not traveling at all and I am guessing that client travel will lessen or change dramatically after this.

The actual salary is a bit lower than what a software engineer in NYC could find, but other perks and benefits, particularly the health care, help to make up for it.

Platinion had to grow rather quickly and made for some hectic and maybe-not-as-thorough recruiting .

This year has especially brought to light shortcomings in Diversity and Inclusion among the nation and BCG is no different. Platinion and especially engineering lacks Black representation and has made strides with but still behind in gender diversity. This year has felt like all the right acknowledgements of the issue have been made; BCG has launched many efforts including 'inclusion accelerators,' millions of dollars in in-kind pro-bono work and actual monetary contributions to causes. But it will take time to tell if a significant positive difference is made.

headline: Bait and Switch for Immigrants
pros:
Has one of the best health insurance in the market
Pay is per market benchmarked standards
Has a profit sharing plan at the end of the year ( in lieu of a 401k match)
Has a lot of parties and free food
Has a fully paid company outing( depends on the office)
Has a education reimbursement policy with approval from manager
Has lot of rewards and freebies thrown in time to time ( like company logo swag) 
People are smart in general and nice to each other
Overseas travel is another plus
Work life balance is optimal
cons:
Very little career mobility within the company
No 401k match
Has periodic layoffs. I have seen lot of people who get rolled off the company if they can't make partner.
The green card policy sucks big time. There is no clear policy that is communicated to the employee. It is very much left at the manager's behest. Managers usually bait and switch the employees using the green card as a tool to keep them. HR is not helpful in resolving such matters. 
Overall, this is a very top down company. It talks a lot about diversity and equality, but if you peel away the layers , none of it is being practiced, in reality. In my case, my manager kept promising a green card filing for 2.5 years without actually filing it, but always making sure to 'bait and switch'. HR will deny any meetings or calls. Immigration team will work in collusion.
To summarize:


No diversity at leadership that can understand issues related to immigration
BCG managers do not fully comprehend issues faced by immigrants
BCG leadership (at Director+ levels) have very little training about the immigration process in this company 
HR does not fully comprehend issues faced by immigrants and are not very helpful
The Green Card process does not provide transparency to the employees, leaving them with zero control of their own situation
 Needless to say, the different players in the BCG immigration team have any accountability to employees as the process itself doesn't call for it

headline: Fallen airline

cons:
-The shift hours. Earliest start is 4:15am. You do get paid for more this, but the damage done to your health is not worth it.
-The workforce is so big that no one knows who you are. You are just a number. Even if you talk to HR or some adminy, they will ask you for your staff number, not our name.
-Due to the huge workforce, many cliques get formed, and the people in the cliques will not talk to you if they don't know you. There would be days when I could go my whole shift without talking to anyone.
-It can be months until you see the same person twice. So if you meet someone that you get along with, you might not see them again for a very long time.
-I only stayed for 7 months. 7 months too long.

headline: Dying cooperation with bad management strategy
pros:
1, constant sample sale, you can find something really really good with like 95% off its original price
2, you get 500 pound share each year, although you can only sell it after two years in the company.
3, there is this amazing share buying scheme where you can buy certain amount of shares. If the shares price go down, you can get your money back at the price you bought it in. if it goes up you can sell your shares at the increased price. and after certain years you will be able to sell your shares tax free.
4, Fruit basket in store and in the office.
5, Generous holiday package, 25days +5 days extra seasonal holidays. if you are in store, you get all bank holiday in liu and you get double pay if you work a bank holiday.
cons:
Burberry is slowing falling out of the customer's favour in recent years. The sales was stagnant before the new designer and it is a struggle to gain new clientele with the new design direction.

result of this is they made the retail staff's life really hard.

1, you get all these new expectations and new duties while your pay stay the same.
2, retail staff get all the blame if the sales is not good.
3, You are constantly policed by managers, visiting head office people on whether you followed every steps they wrote in the customer journey handbook even it is sometimes not very natural.
4, Aggressive sales style expectation. They want you to jump on the customer as soon as they walk in and they want you to ask them to buy everything available in store regardless what they are looking for.
5, They want you to capture all customer's contact details even they are just browsing.
6, No progression in this company, you need to wait 4-5 years to just progress the the next level which only pays for 5k more. They always bring in outsource talent.
7, The HR encourage retail management to be mean and harsh to staff so if the long serving staff don't like the changes they can leave the company themselves. Absolutly toxic work environment. 

8, Last but not the least. Burberry as a big FTSZ 100 cooperation machine. Its lack of agility in reaction to changes are slow and conservative and not suitable for a ever so changing world.

headline: No place for progression or fair salary. Be ready for micromanagement.
pros: Friendly co-workers, multilingual environment, free fruit, employee discounts, sample sales, yearly bonus, city center new office
cons:
I have been here since the office opened. The customer service was moved from London to Leeds and it wasn’t sale-orientated and this was made clear thoroughly the hiring process. No commission, no sales target. Only vouchers based on personal sales, understandable SLAs to respect for quality and response time. This was completely overhauled as the London management left after a few months. The new senior management decided to heavily push on sale with personal targets while putting in place a heavy quality systems that managers would never be able to respect themselves if they were on the phone; still no commission or incentives apart from gift vouchers (CS annual revenue targets shot from 10m to 30m, for a bit of context). Bear in mind you would earn more or less 20k a year, so must be amazing to be able to purchase a couple of cashmere scarves with vouchers instead of getting paid fairly. 

Burberry now pays for the living wage (which is great, right) and English speakers’ salary is around 19k. Language speakers be aware: you will be hired to speak English and a second language for the same money. Yes, this is correct. Native foreign speakers are expected to speak 2 languages while being paid as much as those who can only speak 1 language (unless you consider fair £500 difference, a year). Good luck asking for a raise and no wonder the turn-around is extreme. New positions may arise but they are created to suit specific people, as they already know who they want to give promotions to.

headline: Opportunities
pros: Fantastic work-life balance. As a project manager, I get to work from home. CBRE provides me with all the tools, equipment, resources I need to do my job effectively. My manager doesn’t micromanage me and trusts/allows me to get my work done remotely. Management wants to see us grow and develop. They approached me and asked if there were any certificates I want to pursue to help me become more of an expert in my field. I gave them my proposal and they offered to reimburse me for my expenses without hesitation. I also get the opportunity to interface with upper management both on the CBRE side as well as the client side. This gives me the opportunity to showcase my talents and get on the radars of important decision makers. When I interviewed, the hiring manager advised me that we can receive up to 10% yearly bonus for succeeding in our metrics for the client. I didn’t take it seriously at the time, but he wasn’t BSing. We have been successful and have received the full 10% each year.
cons: Some managers can be more controlling than others. Benefits are mediocre.

headline: So glad to have left
pros: Accumulated stock awards are attractive if you are at the Principal Engineer/Director level
cons:
Two years on from my departure and I still struggle to identify anything remotely positive about Cisco beyond staying for share options. Continual, stealth headcount reductions after each quarter's results have gradually removed those with the energy and creativity that Cisco desperately needs to reinvent itself. For those early-in-career, I'm not convinced that having Cisco on the resume/CV helps. My experience is it can hinder you when applying to new roles as you are tarred with having worked in a slow-moving, behemoth company rather than a fast-moving agile start-up.

Let's face it - this is a company that should have owned the whole videoconference market in the wake of COVID-19 via WebEx yet it is Zoom that has stolen both the zeitgeist and the market. That should be enough for the Board to call for Chuck to step down and for them to bring in a visionary technology leader rather than yet another senior salesperson with a strategy that only looks 2 quarters out in a vain attempt to keep Wall St happy...

hit or or miss managers, once you get a good one its great but they often come and go after a year. 

HR were useless when it came to conflict with co workers. I have left recently because of this, after three years of working in my store and constantly explaining my issues with a particular co worker to new managers and nothing getting done i ended up making a grievance against her in hopes that i could avoid 1 on 1 shifts with her. i gave detailed dates and times of incidents to which they wanted more, which i did. they then did not follow protocol and took far too long to get back to each of us. in the end they dropped my case and dismissed me saying i hadnt got enough evidence and also commented on certain parts of my grievance that were not the core issues and used that against me to ignore all my real issues with bullying and passive aggressive behaviours she had shown towards me my entire career there. 

most stores are under budgeted to an unrealistic extent leaving us understaffed most the time despite being thousands over spent every month. 

managers can work 70 hours and only get paid for 40. a part of their job is to fill in when needed however seeing my most recent manager work a month straight with no days off during covid - even open until closes i could see the company for what it really was, zero compassion.

over all this is an okay job if you get into the right store, obviously a game of dumb luck. in the end three years was enough for me.

headline: Great ideas at the top but...
pros: At Exec level in the company there is a real desire to change the culture of the company. There has been a great focus on diversity and inclusion, mental health support and management training. The support provided to employees during the pandemic has been exceptional. The company is forward looking and has started to focus more on new technologies, digitisation and managed service. Colt's employees are very customer focussed and there appears to be an exciting future for Colt.
cons: There are limited opportunities for personal growth and career development for experienced people. In spite of the excellent management training and a real focus on cultural change at ELT level (including diversity and inclusion) the messages are not filtering down to the managers and past behaviours are still evident. In addition, the day to day pace is frequently exhausting for the operational teams and the amount of change in the business means there is a high level of stress . Unfortunately there are also some small pockets where due to the stress some bullying behaviour is creeping in. There also appear to be many people in "supporting" roles who don't seem to have very much to do can make it difficult for operational people.

headline: Positive culture and a fun place to work
pros: Colt has by far the friendlist corporate culture I've ever experienced. It's not particularly hierarchical, and senior management feels very accessible. Everyone I've reached out to always seems very willing to help and give their time. When mistakes happen, there is not a blame culture but rather an attempt to figure out how things can go better next time. Overall, I feel appreciated and empowered, and really love collaborating with my other team members and people in the wider organisation. I also feel that management is more transparent and honest than other places I've worked. As a woman in tech, it's also good to note that the CEO and half the C-suite are women - the company doesn't make a massive deal out of it, but rather you get the sense that they are letting actions speak louder than words.
cons: Colt has the usual corporate IT and organisation issues - legacy systems, fragmented data, lack of internal visibility, etc. There are efforts to fix this, but it does lead to frustration and lost time / inefficiencies for the time being. However, most large organisations have this problem.

headline: Working at Colt has been the best decision I made!

There's lots of different networks activities to participate in virtually. my favourite thing about being at Colt is the oppotunity to connect with people internationally and learn about other people's cultures. headline: DO NOT WORK HERE, AVOID AT ALL COSTS
pros: They laid me off so I was forced to find another position. This was a godsend.
cons: Where to begin. Truly an unbelievably terrible experience. This company does not care about their employees, from top to bottom. The level of stress I felt was nothing compared to my boss or his boss. The company runs each location like a franchise, rather than a part of the company. Meaning each location is provided well under the level of funding/budgeting they need for staffing. It is impossible to meet any company standards or hit revenue/profitability targets, because you never have enough staff or resources to even be somewhat comfortable. Working here was hell. Constantly running around to try and get through the day, only to be told that your efforts will never be good enough. Trust me when I say to avoid this place. After working here for close to a year, I began to develop anxiety and panic attacks, that got so bad that I needed to go to the hospital. headline: Great People and Career Progression

Countrywide is no different, with the right effort level and results, there is always an opportunity to move the career forward, in my case, Trainee Neg, Neg, Senior Neg, Branch Manager, Senior Branch Manager and Regional Manager - all within 8 years.
None of which would have been possible without being surrounded by great, inspirational people.

headline: Not for everyone. Fine for me.
pros:
Average basic salary. Good earning potential if want to put the work in. 

Good people in lower management.

Lender clients are among the best around.
cons:
Poor tech. Software issues. Booking system is inefficient. 

Rubbish company cars. This is to improve soon, hopefully. 

Rigid operations management. Slow to react to feedback from the field. But will then react suddenly without considering implications. 

Higher management keen to outsource their strategic thought process to the field team and take credit for their ideas. 

Persists with field staff who aren’t team players. Willing to sacrifice quality for coverage. 

Poor benefits. Poor health insurance.

Take the well-being of the staff seriously. Ticking boxes for “wellness” CPD with vague platitudes. Introduce specific and helpful training to help them cope with stress and become more efficient.

headline: The company has changed in the right direction, better pay, better hours and better progression and years gone by

cons: Head Office processes can be quite cross-wired at time.

headline: Keen to reward

The company is keen to reward hard work with regular incentives ranging from time off to vouchers and reviews of targets where these have not been achieved to see if there was good reason for this, leading to discretionary bonuses from time to time.
cons: The IT infrastructure is often problematic, with slow internet and periodic crashes of the main system used.

headline: Leading the way in the Commodification of Higher Education?
pros: Coventry University is a successful business, making large amounts money by continually expanding student numbers.
cons: It could be argued that Coventry University is leading the way in the commodification of Higher Education. In my opinion, too many sacrifices are made (in relation to academic rigour, increasing staff workloads and eroding T&C, not to mention health and safety issues) in order to pursue the goal of good student feedback on the NSS (and thus entice more students to apply next year). headline: Good Nurturing Culture for Graduates but No Career Progression.
pros:
Very helpful senior colleagues in the Leasing Department in Singapore, very willing to help new joiners and rope in for deals, despite possible conflicting interests.

Flexible working hours & a lot of freedom given so long as you get your work done.

Sales team provided with easy access to transport and travel - making access to clients and rushing a day full of site visits a breeze.
cons:
IT systems could generally be improved. Despite investments in IT infrastructure, the upkeep of the sales management system and information database still has room for improvement.

Sometimes there's still a cutthroat culture amidst the sales team which could have been better relieved by the management but management exacerbates it through biased treatment based on relationships. 

Real estate industry tends to be a bit more traditional so if you're looking for something more dynamic and you want to go places, it's tough to rise up through the ranks as people are generally comfortable at where they are.

When I left, the profit sharing incentives were getting tougher and being cut into because of the top management who wanted a large cut of the deals. This greatly affected the sales team's motivation to work & perform.
