headline: *Attention College Grads** DHL - The Supervisor - Do you have what it takes?
pros:
For a College Graduate coming into this as a first job, this is just about the best job if you want the following:
1. To learn as much as possible, as quickly as possible, about Supply Chain as a whole .
2. To gain high level management skills by being thrown into the fire
3. Make it "to the top" of the industry, in terms of knowledge, as fast as possible
4. If you consider yourself extremely driven and a hard worker
5. Consider yourself "hard to rattle" and very much an extrovert

Overall this experience is a good way to get a crash course in SCM, as long as you are willing to accept what that is going to take. Get in and get out after a year, or 2 if you can handle it.
cons:
These pro's are great, but they are all that DHL explains to you when you are applying and being recruited from College and they came at a cost. The following are some examples:

1. For the first year, you will almost certainly work on a night shift (either 3pm-11pm or 11pm - 7am)
2. You will be getting there at LEAST an hour before your shift and often times staying anywhere from 1 - 4 hours after the shift depending on your site.
3. Hardly anybody makes it past a year from the college recruit program because of these reasons:
 3a. You will be worked harder than anybody you graduated with and most likely make less (Standard right now is $52,500 out of college)
 3b. You will miss out on most of your life that year
 3c. No matter what they say, Management (except for a few diamonds in the rough) do NOT care about you, they are trying to stay afloat. 
 3d. No matter how well you do, the few negative things will be the main daily talking points
 *** 3e. For example, I had 10 guys and girls I started with around the country that I got to know: 8 of them have already left after a year, and the last 2 are desperately trying to find another job.
4. The people that generally succeed here from this role are generally the "a-hole leaders" that only care about getting promoted, and they generally do not know what they are doing and push you to make up for it
5. It will probably take you about 4-5 years to make it to an OM position, making ~$70,000, and your first OM role will be a "disaster site" or a start up, where you will work more than you ever have before.
6. You will not have even the slightest work life balance
7. Everyone in upper management brags about how much they work and have worked in the past. The first and most common tip I got was to "never calculate how much I made per hour"

If you think you can handle these things for a year, I'd say absolutely go for it. It's great experience. Some of the Con's are just a part of being the base level of Supply Chain, but some of them could definitely be fixed or worked on. BUT, if you don't think you can handle this, please consider other options. It will make even the hardest and smartest workers second guess their abilities.

headline: Behind the neat uniforms its all a bit chaotic and unprofessional...
pros: Free food sometimes and working with some decent people. Pay is probably marginally better than similar jobs elsewhere (19.5k)
cons:
- Chaotic nature of working in logistics
- Too much expected of CSA`s who earn barely above minimum wage
- Management who are just interested in padding stats to make themselves look good, even at the expense of providing a respectable level of customer service
- Drivers (and management) will straight up lie about things (such as going back to re attempt deliveries) to CSA`s which causes more issues and even angrier customers
- No real job prospects as a CSA, If you want to move up and have to deal with the even greater stress of a management position you will need to start off in Ops rather than customer service
- senior management have told CSA`s that they are only expected to be in the position for about 18 months before leaving. This says it all really about how customer services is viewed within the company
- Management cannot be challenged on anything and will shut down employees if they try to question processes etc, quite often this is done in an unprofessional manner that leads exployees to feel that they are not respected
- One of DPD`s core values is supposed to be "accountability" yet every level of the company is very quick to wash their hands of a problem and pass it onto the next person
- The very top level of management seem so far removed from what its actually like working in one of their depots that they rarely make changes that benefit employees. As previously mentioned stats are falsified from drivers, shift managers, ops managers, depot managers, regional managers etc all the way up the chain so that everyone looks good. The people who suffer as a result are customers and then customer service agents who spend their days dealing with the fallout of these decisions.
- Poor work life balance, long sometimes unsociable hours in a mentally draining job

headline: They dont care about you your just a number which can be easily replaced
pros: Some drivers are nice and helpful and that's it
cons:
Make sure you have a smart phone as their satnav will take you to the wrong street at least two times a shift.
If you are a little late for work they will give your route to someone else, when you start at 4.30am they expect you to be out within an hour but then you have to find a loading bay, if you find a loading bay you have to find your parcels which most of them are in one place but then the others could be anywhere and you end up looking for them for three hours, and when you are in that early they sometimes are still taking parcels off the lorry as it turned up late and they wont tell you before you turn up so your waiting three hours to get your parcels yet again.
When there is high winds you still have to work at the same price. They expect you to deliver your parcels in the time slots given even though the satnav takes you to the wrong place, and as they dont keep you on the same route you cant get used to finding the difficult properties. 
If you cant find a property and bring the parcel back they will send you back out to deliver it even if that mean it's in a different city.
Working weekends is chaos there about 3 management on shop floor who everyone crowds around so your waiting ages to get some help, on the weekends you still have to deliver to businesses which they know are closed, so you could have 30 boxes to one business which is closed so you have to keep climbing over them to get to other parcels which then eats into your time and if you end up late delivering a parcel they wont care, they have no common sense as they expect you to wear safety boots while you walk from your van to your car and the reason they give is that if you get run over it will save you but in reality shoes are not going to save anything when you get run over, if you refuse to wear the boots walking to your car they will punish you. If you cant find a parcel they wont take it off they expect you to find it so while your searching for it for 3 hours they expect you to deliver on time, you can work 12 hour shifts. Sometimes your parcels can weigh 30kg.
They will lie to you, they hire loads of drivers at busy periods give them false hope but when it's a quiet period they will fire them or force them out.

headline: Poor treatment, poor pay
pros: The discount is quite good.
cons: The company cares more about selling their credit card than actually providing customer service, they bully the staff into pushing this card on customers as well as pushing for emails, they tell you not to ask customers if they want to be added to the mailing list they just told us to tick the box. The pay is poor for what you are expected to do, as a senior I only made 45p more than a sales assistant and I was threatened that my pay would be taken off me if I told others what I made. Money was no better if you were a supervisor, they made 20p more than a senior but they were told to be ‘mini managers’ without the benefit of a managers salary. There was little training given, you learnt on the job and taught be people who were already stretched think while management sat upstairs. Progression was kept for those who sucked up to management and not those who were better or more competent at the job. There is no consistency, in Cheshire Debenhams we went through 6 managers in the four years I was there, only two were actually good at their job and genuinely cared for staff. Staff turn over is awful, we lost 8 members of staff in a few months because the could no longer cope with the stress management put on them. Generally a very poor place to work, staff on the floor were left completely demotivated, it was hard to get staff to come in for overtime as they just didn’t want to be in the store.

headline: Great Place to work - not a meritocracy!

cons:
It is not a meritocracy. If you work twice as hard as the next person, they will say thank you. Your career won’t benefit.

headline: Only apply if you enjoy being a perpetual temp with no benefits
pros: None that I could think of.
cons:
The "temps" here work for years for this company. Some people go years without having raises  or raises so minuscule one wonders if it was a joke .  A lot of them make ends meet by doing copious amounts of overtime. Since DB is the biggest customer of these temp agencies, be prepared for them to drop you should you complain about DB's horrid work environment. Management is clueless at best and malicious at worst. There is this one manager that not only treats the deaf employees badly, but she makes it her mission to go to different departments NOT under her supervision just so she can get her kicks from having people fired. Many employees have complained about her but nothing is done since she's a permanent employee of DB and the people complaining are temps. As for other managers, they promote the laziest and biggest brown-nosers imaginable to lead positions and then wonder why work isn't get done. Instead they blame the grunts who are actually doing the work for the screwups. The volume of work is increasing daily but instead of hiring more, they just expect everybody to work weekends. Unsurprisingly, the turnover is high all around.

This company just fired a hundred people because they outsourced most of the processing to a different country.  All those temp agencies bending over backwards was for naught.  Expect neither loyalty, fairness or even competency from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Great business that lets internal politics get in the way.
pros:
Amazing brands with big A&P budgets. 
Great culture (friendly people, flexible working, great parental leave).
Good benefits and salary. 
Very creative environment to work and a great place to build your creative excellence.
cons:
Leadership
The standard of leadership is quite poor - don't expect a coaching culture.
If you want to be seen as a talented employee, you need to be able to play the political game, build relationships with the right people and agree with whatever they say. A large portion of senior leaders have gotten to where they are because of their ability to play the game, not because they are experts in their field. This is the foundation of why Diageo is so bad at execution of plans. 

Values
Sad to say, the company values are just some words on a website, they are not practiced or enforced. There is a lot of poor behaviour from senior leaders that goes against Diageo's values but goes ignored (bullying, favouritism and neglecting team members).

Global Culture
The Diageo culture I mention in the 'pro list' above, sadly is for the UK only. The business has not succeeded in embedding the UK culture in all markets. If I had to rate the Diageo USA or Africa cultures, it would be a different story.

headline: It is what you make of it
pros:
Relatively secure job and flexible working arrangements. Equiniti has been fantastic throughout the COVID period. No redundancies or pay cuts as far as I'm aware. 

If you have a good relationship with senior management, you have the opportunity to move between different divisions, try new job roles and progress quickly within the company. 

Equiniti is making an effort to keep staff healthy and motivated with mindfulness and mental health sessions, fitness challenges and started a working from home hub where teams can share recipes, home schooling tips and other information.
cons:
Weak business model and a lack of investment in platforms and products has hindered innovation and development. There seems to be an acceptance of legacy IT systems and processes that have impacted both individual and business-level efficiency.

The acquisition of companies over the years appears to have clouded Equiniti's focus and has led to funding being stretched thinly across numerous divisions. 

While many of the senior management team and directors are competent and able, some have been at the company since the start of their careers and have relatively little experience and, or, minimal qualifications compared to peers at comparable organisations. Nice to see people climbing the ranks but worth keeping on top of the market and seeing whether external candidates could bring more to the role.

headline: Outdated and unevolved company
pros: The people here encourage not working in weekends. Also there is a 10 working day mandatory leave which should be taken every year.
cons:
I joined with high hopes of setting up a new technology in this company and worked hard towards achieving that. But my efforts were never considered and they even gave me the lowest rating possible without actually giving me a project. 
The politics here is so bad. There is a constant standoff between managers even within the same company and that impacts you as well. You aren't allowed to help the another team from the same company or be seen talking with other vertical people in the company. This gives you a bad reputation. You will be continuously micro managed as well.
I was assured multiple times that I will get a project. But I still feel, there wasn't enough effort taken to bring projects to offshore. And yeah there is continuous rift between onsite and offshore as to who will get the projects. I am not sure why this petty mindset is there.
Appraisals and compensation aren't fair as well. The process for the appraisal needs to change. But this pretty much is there in every company. So I would advice the compensation be fair on the employees.
There are also a few other things I wish not to talk about but are prominent in the company.

To be clear I am talking about one of the verticals in this company. There are multiple verticals like this. I really hope atleast the ones working in that vertical are happy and satisfied with the job.
I would never recommend anyone to join this company unless the culture here changes

headline: Just operations. Zero innovation.
pros: It's interesting to see how FB operates.
cons: I was promised a role at the intersection of tech leadership, product strategy and people management. But it was nothing like that at all. I essentially spent 100% of my time doing operational things that I didn't enjoy, like following bureaucratic processes. Directions for the team were set from the top. People are moved around like pawns because of frequent reorgs. Everyone behaved like a career-obsessed robots, always looking for ways to game PSCs. But the most frustrating feeling of all was that I didn't see anyone try to innovate in any way. All the products efforts that I witnessed were either about copying a competitor or leveraging/abusing FB's dominant position in some market to push features to users (in a way that always serves FB's interest first and the user's interest second).

headline: Bad direction, no critical feedback of first-time managers
pros:
Overall compensation
Top tech kit
Some areas are very promising
cons:
When joining, I picked Shops because it was a promising project, but after I made my decision, it was clear that the Org was notoriously disorganised. The project has lost most of its key personnel because the Director for Product was unable to give a clear direction, and censored all the reasonable ideas. My manager was inexperienced and refused to hear any suggestion that I made. It felt really demoralising and frustrating. I reached out to other managers, friends from previous job who agreed that it was frustrating… but that’s it.
– I agree, this is a horrible situation.
– What can I do about it?
– I don’t know…
– Wait a year, so I can change teams?
– Maybe. That was changed to 18 months though.

All three of the Org, the project and my manager had "the worst Pulse rating in the history of the company" at their level, according to people who had been at Facebook longer. No one reached out.

Several key stakeholders left, notably one senior Data engineer. I offered to take over some of their workload because I knew how and I badly needed data to do my own work. That was yet another suggestion that my manager shut down.

It got tiring really fast.

headline: Empowering mission-driven work.  Driving positive societal changes everyday.
pros: Facebook prioritises building positive social impact. They do this over growing revenue and this creates a hugely incredible mission-driven company. You are empowered to align personal and team goals to invent the products and outcomes to build social good. Every person that you work with at Facebook has this mindset, creating an incredibly supportive and collaborative environment where everyone is an ally.
cons: Facebook isn't for everyone. The hardest thing that many people struggle with is the amount of ownership and accountability you are given. Because Facebook is so bottoms-up, it requires people to be able to be highly collaborative to gather information to make the right decision. No one is going to tell you what to work on, you have to decide yourself what will be most impactful. That's a hard environment to be successful in for many.

headline: Big on Micromanagement with Pockets of Progress
pros:
Able to work from home during pandemic. 
Relaxed dress code.
Friendly and knowledgable staff. 
Support functions able to buy additional annual leave.
When managers are good they are really good. 
Helpful and friendly I.T. Department.
Forward thinking and passionate L&D team (though stifled by traditional company outlook).
Some progressive policies in the works and a technological overhaul is ongoing.
cons:
Many mid and high level managers are very old school, sections of the business feel like they are run entirely differently to others with a negative and unproductive culture. 
It is only through sheer luck that you’ll have a manager with the skills and passion to help you develop. (Though if you do there are some good opportunities).
Salary is very low especially for the area and pay reviews are often meagre. 
A lot of time dedicated to talking in a progressive, albeit overly corporate language, with little concrete results so far. 
Company communications are often vacuous and unhelpful.
Helpful and progressive functions and policies are often removed or allowed to expire with no replacement in place. E.g. our non-core benefits and recognition platform both expired and have yet to be replaced. 
Lack of sideways progression for skilled roles, only real route forward is into senior or management positions, causing the company to be very top heavy.

headline: A great place to start your career

Training readily available and lots of colleagues to support learning

Buy/ sell annual leave 
Company seems stable and wfh during Covid was prompt and well organised
Flexible working policy (outside of Covid) seems to be on the horizon
Company invests in digital upgrades and it feels like a modern company in that respect 
Visible CEO
Local IT department is great
Casual dress code
Onsite parking available & within walking distance of town centre
Work life balance at entry level is great
cons:
A lot of stress put on middle managers - work/life imbalance is very visible
Personal development not a required focus for people leaders, it seems more of a bonus if your manager is proactive in this area. 
Communication is "need to know" only, leading to unnecessary rumour mill 
Not all of the company is on board with modern ways of working and sometimes plays catch up with other areas 
Salary details on internal vacancies withheld
New Milton office is not wheelchair accessible (narrow corridors and no lift). I am not sure they could accommodate a wheelchair user in the office at all
Resourcing is slow - offers of employment take weeks, salary insights not available and interview feedback not forthcoming - it is unclear what responsibilities lie with hiring manager/ resourcing, almost always leaving candidates in the dark for longer than is courteous.
Comms are often trite and, at times, patronising
Not many green initiatives
Diversity of the exec is low
Salary not competitive (but benefits, training & work life balance compensate a little for this)

headline: The worst job
pros:
I liked some of my colleagues

Very diverse company
cons:
Work/life balance is appalling. You work 53.5hrs Monday to Friday. And you work every other Saturday. Getting home and having about 30mins to myself a day after cooking, washing etc. was soul destroying. Looking for another job on top of this was awful.

17 days holiday -  It is 20 days, but you have to take 3 between Christmas and New Year, when the office is closed! 

The general public do not trust you.

COVID - they seemed to think we were above Covid restrictions. Contact tracing was ignored, social distancing was ignored, quarantine periods were ignored, PPE rules were ignored. This was in one office out of around 60, so I'm sure there was more.

Staff turnover - it is a revolving door because of how terrible a job it is.

Company car scam - the lightest scratch on your company car will cost you £600, at least.

All you do all day is call people.

High-street estate agents not what they were 10yrs ago, they used to have almost 30% market share today they have 5% and offices dealt with more applicants, today that is saturated with over 60 branches. Heavily corporate, you are no more than a statistic. There is a lot of internal promotion - however, most likely only when someone expands/dies/moves on.

headline: A good place to start
pros: As far as Engineering goes, I really enjoy the people and have found many mentors (both senior and peer). People are smart and come from various backgrounds. Diverse thinking and cool personalities. There is a strong emphasis on networking, which creates a pervasive "catch-up over coffee" culture. I entered post-undergrad, and I like being able to choose between working back-end/service-side and front-end, and learning a little bit of everything, not necessarily stuck to one thing (though my specialty is Java). Team culture varies depending on the leadership of your team. My first team was not too entry-level friendly, but my team did genuinely care about my growth and had my back; I always felt that I was treated with respect. Overall I've had a pretty positive experience with working in a team and working to my own schedule. Since pandemic I've been working remotely, and the plan is to move forward with a mixed approach (2-3 days in office, 2-3 days working remote from home). Engineering teams do seem open and willing for the mixed-work style moving forward as well, which is good. Internal mobility is always an option and people are willing to help you out. Amenities in the New York office, such as the gym and the cafe, are very nice.
cons: If your main concern is money, you might as well look for a job at a tech company. Could definitely be getting paid better elsewhere. Office politics is definitely a thing. If you're interested in stocks/trading, working at a bank will put restrictions on that. My current team is based in EMEA and is definitely more suited for developing new engineers, but dealing with time difference, keeping in the loop, and making space for myself in project tasks (from the perspective of being based in Americas) has proven frustrating at times.

headline: Rushed out the Door
pros: Free food, nice offices, resources for mental health that you'll probably need after working there for a while.
cons:
In my experience the focus has been on rushing something out the door. Not necessarily something good, or something completely functional (even for the minimal features in the MVP), just something. Frequently software is rushed, testing is skimped on, and higher up engineers are unwilling to learn modern software development practices to improve software performance, reliability, developer experience, and user experience.

If you do not like to cut corners, do not work at Google. After spending 4 years here, being told by 3 managers that I care too much about my work and spend too much time making it right (while simultaneously being dinged on perf for it being 'not right enough'), and witnessing Google's willingness to protect sexual abusers and the bottom line over its purported values, the veneer of friendliness seems very disingenuous.

headline: Avoid CAST Belfast!
pros: Some of the management where approachable, however they have left the business recently. You can WFH
cons:
They expect you to work additional hours with no overtime rate and then they decide when you can take the time back. They are currently going through a restructure and the current management team decided to split everyone into different teams just for the sake of it. The senior managers lack any interpersonal skills and are extremely fake. CAST Belfast is calculated with regards to promotion opportunities and this is pre judged, people in the management team have all worked together previously in different companies this is not coincidental as it's happened a few times.. in short you are expected to do accounting work and get minimum wage.
 There are lots of tasks and if you cant complete a complex one you will be performance managed, even of you can do all the other tasks, example -i cant complete a really difficult task but I'm great at al others, I will be performance managed, if im in a team that does a simple task my role is safe. The senior management team have no idea what they are doing, in particular the director who reads what he is told to read and is so disingenuous. I know my colleagues feel the same way and you will start to see good people leaving due to the uncertainty. Bonus is a disgrace,
you would be better off working in McDonalds! They are making it up as they go along. Avoid CAST at all costs, this part of Grant Thornton is not what it seems. People in the wrong jobs.this is my personal opinion and I hope they fix it! Watch how many people leave now!

headline: It was as expected
pros: Best people to work with. Very friendly people and managers until a new manager came. People from different floors will be reassigned to help even out the busy floors. Ok pay but could be more.
cons: Was given over time even though I didn’t ask for it. My contract was meant to be 20 hrs but the new manager kept regularly assigning me at least 38 hours per week. Her excuse was that it’s because I was working hard so she thought I’d want more hours. I was a student ofc I couldn’t take more hours. Next was that she’d guilt us into staying for longer. E.g my shift ended at 7pm on Fridays and I’d finish my last task but everytime on my way to the staff room she’d say stuff like omgg you can’t leave look at the busy tills even though my colleagues whom I paged in advance were already there to take my place. She’d also try to make me help her by saying it’s just one last thing but add a bunch of things to it at the end. She’d try make it seem like we are all expected to leave the store late and she expected overtime from all of us regardless of our personal situation. If we didn’t she’d say things like how can you leave this to your colleagues, they want to go home too (even though it’s not their time to leave yet), if you stay behind and help they can leave early etc, without taking into account that I had uni in the morning and it was already 1am. Needless to say I didn’t stay long enough to get any offers. But before the new manager came, it was a lovely supportive place. We’d meet our goals and our then manager would help us on the floor if we were too overwhelmed. The new manager would just be on her phone.

headline: Avoid if possible
pros:
1. Chance to build relationships with people at some of the largest fashion brands
2. Discount was good, but only useful in the foodhall
3. Comradery with other people at your level who are going through the same things.
cons:
1. Work life balance was horrendous. Routinely had to stay in the office until past 10pm and was expected back in at 9am
2. Very hierarchical office atmosphere and structure. Looked down upon by everyone above you. Was told by my manager to work harder so managemnt made their bonuses.
3. No room for progression or taking on new responsibilities. Was told by my manager to “remember your job description”.
4. Office culture is generally toxic with a culture of presenteeism. 
5. No emphasis on diversity. The only diversity is on the shop floor. Pretty much everyone in the office is white and female.
6. For entry level roles it was not a great work environment. Little chance to truly develop and build skill base. Working here is only for the name on the CV of you have to take the job.

headline: They need a complete team (manager level) makeover
pros:
It’s the people who make you stay
Brands you get to work on
And the discounts were great
cons:
No career progression or raise, will ONLY happen (e.g a mere 2k more, with a somewhat important sounding title change) if it benefits the manager e.g will mean they have more free time to go to pointless interviews in fancy private members clubs and not do any actual work. 
The head of has no clue what’s going in the team nor do they care, they spend all their time in Knightsbridge and not in the Hammersmith office with their team, once they were no where to be seen for at least 2 months!! 
The whole of the old digital marketing team has left, which speaks volumes!! the new managers they’ve hired are friends they’d made at previous jobs (with hardly any relevant experience). One of the roles was on the careers site for a day before it got taken down and GIVEN to their FRIEND.

headline: Dont work here
pros: best pro i found was leaving
cons:
This is the worst job i have ever worked at in my life. The training process was great, Dan young gave me a advert for the great place this will be to work ( i was wrong) Once you're out of the training process another thing which was good was the academy period which lasted around 3 weeks with Dharon Pitt this was also a good advert. Unfortunately this was where it ended and the emotional destruction and, blackmail and micro management started. 

If a phone call comes in and they're not going to renew because they've sold there car so, don't require the insurance, this is your fault, WHY DIDN'T YOU RENEW THEM!! If someone rings through and they've told you twice they don't want to renew, make sure you badger them and harass them and stress the customer out because that's what you're told to do. or when a customer comes through and would like to speak to a manager, good luck trying to find one who can justify why they're paid more and actually take the call over from you, you will be told to say this and say that when really the customer would like to speak to the manager, either way it's your fault for even bothering the manager whilst they have a good catch up about social lives etc. 

When you have your 15 minuet break times don't you dare go 30 seconds over it because this will result in a good talking too and making you feel as though you are a child in school. i understand and appreciate someone being late but this is a new meaning. One thing that is great is the bribery, often when the managers or senior members of the staff need a good review in order to keep there job, they'll bribe you, what with? a Kit-Cat was mine, i was so excited i couldn't wait to write about how awesome the culture and workplace was here! if you renew 15 customers in a row without using any time to breath while standing on your head you earn yourself... a TV? Money? a car? no a celebration (not the box a single celebration) 

If you have any sort of mental health, anxiety, or any emotional imbalance avoid working here as a CR. this will finish you off. They often try to promote there 4C's message which is Colleagues, Customers, Company, Community. a great message which starts with colleagues meaning it will benefit the next part and so on, its a shame they done actually do this, if you're feeling down, get back on the phone, late for work due to a car crash, get back on the phone, if your whole family is in a life threatening situation, please please just get back on the phone. if you're feeling down, depressed, suicidal and would love to go home due to you not being able to reach your maximum potential...then please go you need it ( but just expect your disciplinary on your desk tomorrow) but please go if that's what you wanna do. 

i was often asked to stay past contracted hours in order to get through the call ques, despite this not being in my contract it was expected otherwise you should say goodbye to your job. You're also bombarded with awful stat expectations, and when you've had a good day? could do better, when you've had a perfect 100% day there is very little recognition or acknowledgment for this, I'm sure a lot of people who are under this pressure want a 100% day just so they don't have to hear the same broken record about how this is all because of you, you're not doing enough you're not saying what we told you, you didn't do this you didn't do that, be prepared to speak like a robot, but please add some character and personality in there (whilst you repeat exactly what we've said and follow a script) 

There is so many things wrong here, at first i felt i could've been harsh but no this is exactly how its run, it's a schoolground mentality with the managers thinking they're the teachers and own you but life changing consequences, which is loosing your job, I'm sorry to anyone who didn't see this and now works there and to anyone who's reading this and doesn't work here..Don't.

headline: Not for me
pros: The salary is good compared to other agencies
cons: I joined Hays as an experienced consultant who had previously a successful contact desk billing over 250k a year. The interview process was like the xfactor but was relatively ok. When I started we were told how lucky we were to have secured a place at Hays and that many other consultants across the country would dream to be in our position. Thought that was a little odd and this really was what most employees at the office believed, that they were inferior to others in the industry. We were set unrealistic and unachievable targets which we had to present the outcome off to the rest of the new starters, HR and the MD. As an experienced consultant I put a lot of pressure on myself to achieve these however when I didn’t and was faced with telling the MD, HR and the other new starters it really dented my confidence as failing to hit KPIs wasn’t something I was used to. However during the presentation it very quickly became clear that none of the other 10 new starters had hit their targets either and after speaking with other colleagues I found out that most people didn’t even come close to hitting their targets either when they started. It seems a strange process to put new starters through and certainly caused a lot of us undue stress. I do wonder why Hays haven’t looked at this and changed it as it was clear the targets were unachievable which was proved by not one person hitting them. I guess this would be a fair reflection of how the company is run, out of date and corporate. There was little training on the industry of your desk, I wasn’t trained on payroll despite having 5 people out working for me and the CRM system is hard to use, slow and isn’t fit for purpose. Consultants also don’t have their own numbers which is bizarre, there is an office number which one of 35+ people could answer. I left after 4 months and am now much happier, even if I was ‘lucky’ to have secured the opportunity there.

headline: A good place to work if you're based in a city and aren't salary focused!
pros:
An enormous variety of roles available, with flexible working as standard across most.
Fantastic, hardworking and supportive colleagues
The organisation has come on in leaps and bounds, in terms of technology and culture, in recent years meaning that the switch to home working at the start of the first lockdown was instant and almost entirely free of frustration. It was fantastic to just be able to carry on working productively and safely from home while my friends and family working elsewhere had all sorts of obstacles to overcome.
cons:
No jobs now available outside of large cities due to smaller offices all being closed
No matter how hard you work or how well you perform, pay rises are still non-existent in the department (any rises awarded have been below inflation, so in real terms, pay cuts). This has been the case for ten years now and given the amount the government have had to spend to fight Covid-19, its very unlikely that salaries will increase in the near future

headline: Good place to learn.
pros: Very friendly, good for building skills, lots of opportunities, industry leader in the application of Agile, felt like you were doing something good (generating income for the UK). Very progressive in terms of digital.
cons: Bogged down by Civil Service processes, grading system is so alien to people who havent worked there before. Felt like we were in a bubble sometimes, as we were delivering digital services so quickly and in an agile way, then you'd have to connect up to the world outside of HMRC digital and you would have to slow down, go through gate processes, fight egos of service managers who owned telephony and paper services. Also, at that point there was no wifi, so you couldn't use the internet when in breakout areas. There was no work from home solution either which was really difficult. Management were shifted into weird roles too - people with no experience in digital specialisms were given 'heads of' roles because they were the right grade. It felt quite insulting to people who had years of experience.

headline: Good work life balance but poor pay and progression opportunities.
pros: Good work life balance with flexible working hours. Understanding and supportive management for the most part. Responsibility for your own work can gives a great sense of achievement.
cons:
Progression opportunities in technical tax fields severely limited outside of the inspector training program (TSP). Program is only open for applications once a year to start the following year, there is no advantage for internal staff over external and success is based on assessment centre performance rather than qualification and or/experience.
As a result many experienced staff either stay underpaid at lower grades becoming frustrated or leave to work in private firms where their experience is valued and rewarded. 
There is also poor representation of minorities in senior grades for a department that is very diverse.

headline: Very Flexible and easy job
pros:
-Flexi time- you can work more time Monday to Thursday then Leave early on Friday 2:30 pm
-you can build up time during a week or 2 and have a day off. Or for example if your family or friends are going for a day out, you can take the day off as flexi time, then just work the time back during the next few weeks.
-you can also leave early if something came up and need to go somewhere different city or anything else and use it as flexi and work it back, so overall with flexi time you can pretty much decided which days you want to take off , no pressure whatsoever , you can also take 9 days to the next annual working year carry on.
-Also you can can carry upto 3 days of flexi leave days to the next month, so you work more hours during the current month and build up so you can have 3 extra days off next month
-for example, a friend of mine used all their annual leave during the year, then his friends wanted to go a week holiday, but i he had 2 annual leave days left, so he worked extra during the month and 3 days off extra next month during the holiday, the line manager has to agree with it but all managers agree.
-you can start anytime between 6:30am and 10am, its 7 hours 24 minutes a day work, but people normally work 7:30 mins a day and 30 mins break so 8 hours a day monday to thursday, then friday leave 30 mins early.
-the latest you work till is 7pm, unless the line manager agrees for you to work more to certain circumstances.
-you can have small breaks during you work time quick 5-10 mins, i normally go our for fresh air, alot of people go out to smoke regularly, it doesnt count part of your break. minimum break time is 30 mins but you can have an hour you just work 30 mins extra, if you want more you can for example 1 hour 30 mins or 2 hours just speak to manager they will let you, you just have to work it back.
-many career opportunities - you can apply to internal jobs once you pass you probation after 6 months, i am going to start EO job soon, i started AO 6 months ago, i got a provisional offer, they are currently doing checks could take few weeks or months not sure,
cons: nothing to complain about to be honest

headline: Good place to get your feet wet in the tech world
pros:
- IBMers are known for being genuine, nice people. I haven't experienced cattiness, aggression, or any other negative interactions.
- Brand recognition is high--having the name on your resume is good even if the company isn't as prolific as it once was
- There's a big emphasis on professional development with endless resources
- Excellent work/life balance--I rarely work past 5 PM
- Big budgets to try out different marketing efforts
- Working with brilliant, well-educated, respected SMEs is both humbling and exciting
cons:
- IBM is an enormous legacy tech company governed by bean counters, compliance officers, legal teams, and others who minimize our risk. It can be over-bearing at times. Processes always change, and usually not for the better.
- Lack of junior support on most teams. You'll have director-level and lead-level employees stretched thin because they're still doing the same responsibilities even after they're promoted
- Some department execs are lifers (20+ years) which is good and bad. They know the inner machinations, but also tend to be less risk averse or have limited understanding of how marketing happens outside our company
.- We are using email software older than I am and have no plans to migrate off the platform anytime soon.
- IBM has an uncertain future. While other tech companies are booming we're reducing in size. How is that possible?

headline: Lots its vision
pros: For the most past Indeed was a great place to work for many years. The people were great, the pay was decent and leadership was very understanding through all of covid. The health benefits were amazing and you could really take a lot of the unlimited PTO is you were doing your work the rest of the time.
cons:
The biggest con is that leadership and the company seem to be adrift. A lot of senior members of the leadership team have left in the last 9 months and the company has seemed to have lost its way. They are constantly putting new product tweaks in place that are hurting employers and aren't wanted by them. The engineering teams seem to think they know what the clients wants but sales and CS, on the front lines, are having to deal with angry employers and having to explain why they are getting a worse ROI month after month. The company also keeps investing in side projects that don't work and are spending too long on them and too much money.

There is also a lot of lip service about DE&I but other than IRGs there isn't a lot of changes happening in management.

pros: Unlimited PTO, free meals, cool office aesthetics, smart colleagues, some friendly people to work with.
cons:
When I first started, Indeed had more of a laid back "startup" feel. That started to fade away when it grew tremendously in 2016, 2017, 2018, etc. Indeed has a "no jerks" policy, but that didn't seem to be applied as much as the years went on. Top talent people from the West and East Coast were brought in for brainpower, but with that often came huge egos and underdeveloped emotional intelligence/social skills. Entitled "geniuses" started roaming around the office.

Pay was also quite low for my department. Some departments might of been different, but they claimed all of the cushy techy perks were justification for below average pay. This was in Austin when the housing/rent prices began skyrocketing as an influx of transplants kept rolling in. 

Management was pretty incompetent in my department. Lots of favoritism and college cliquey vibes that got unqualified people promoted if they were within that clique.

There was a lot of pressure to hang out at the office as much as possible. It was a good gig for recent grads, but a lot of people had their entire lives and identifies embedded in the Indeedian work culture. If you didn't want to partake in all of that, it was a bit to your disadvantage.

headline: Great company to work and learn from.
pros: You will get to learn and touch different technologies. There are so many processes in place that its too hard to fail at your job. Vendor support is always available, JPMC offers access to pluralsight videos for free. Soft skills is very important in this company, so thats something that is picked up along the way. Pre covid, if the budget is there you have the opportunity to request offsite training. I got to attend vendor conventions representing JPMC. Vendors will throw goodies at you when they see you work this big company, vendors also took care of us by providing free lunch. Pay is good, so are benefits.
cons: While the processes are good to adhere by, sometimes it makes it difficult to get your work done. Change management and incident managers are not technical, therefore it makes it a challenge to get your technical point across. If your someone who doesn't like talking to an audience, this will present challenges. Network team is flooded with tickets and user requests. Anytime something breaks, the network team is the first one to get called. The mind set in the technology space is that anytime something breaks "its the network".

headline: Avoid - Worst employer I have worked for
pros:
Good pension. 
Access to O'Reilly.

Not a nice atmosphere. Bullying atmosphere sometimes, particularly from management. The way that one manager spoke to me was awful on one occasion, totally unprofessional.

I was aware of several people on PIPs (performance improvement plans) including myself - about 5 people, out of an office of only 50 people. I knew two of these people, and thought they were on a PIP unfairly. I think mine was unfair too. All 3 of us left the company shortly afterwards.

Cleaners didn't do the kitchen area. So all developers had a rota. When it was your turn, you had to take everyone's mugs, put in the dishwasher, take them out, etc... everywhere else I have worked has hired a cleaner to do this.

Lack of work when I was there. One developer was placed on a manual testing job for about 2 months. He left because of it. He was one of the people on a PIP and told me that he thought he'd been placed on this job because the company wanted him to quit.

headline: Fake in being fake
pros: Nice building located in central London with good facilities. Decent pay.
cons:
The company culture is good when it comes to what you can find in their written policy and how the senior management describes it, but it’s nothing like that when it comes to how they actually act. In fact, what you’ll find is a fake system which pretends to cares about diversity and inclusion, be discrimination free, encourages innovation /creativity and provides predictable and transparent communication. With regards to some of these fundamental principles of a good company culture, they don’t even bother to fake it properly. On my action of challenging some of them, authority and the fact that I don’t have the required understanding of such matters has been invoked to me.
My general feeling on working at Knight Frank can be reduced to some of my experience in dealing with rental property agents, where the main goal was to make easy money by all means. If I can accept this in the rental business, I find it outrageous to see it applied in a technical environment by the upper management.
In short, if you don’t like to be asked to put a smile on your face when the manager wants it, if you don’t want to be hearing lies which may affect your development path, if you don’t want to be putting a lot of effort in delivering projects which are meant to be tick box exercises for your manager and if you want to be yourself and respected for being so, then Knight Frank is not the company you are looking for. On the other hand, if you have no problem with being a yes man, if you care more about money than you care about the working environment, if you don’t have a strong technical background and no plans of improving it and if you don’t worry too much if the management layer uses your work to collect credits without recognizing your effort, then Knight Frank might be a good fit for you.
The human resources are just a bad joke. How else could they be in such an environment? It is ruled by the well-known principles of defending the management layer and making sure that they say how much care is put in the so-called company culture, but, based on my experience with them, it shows as an extreme version of such approach.
So, in my understanding, Knight Frank is toxic working environment which should be avoided as much as possible.

headline: Questionable commission allocation system, constraining and archaic rules for women, you have to pay for uniform shoes
pros: During christmas the commission is good, but it doesn't make up for all of the cons.
cons: You might think the perks and discounts would be great, but you actually have to pay for your uniform every season! You must purchase one pair of new shoes every time the season changes, which means they can't be on sale or an old design. It's 75% discount on one pair of full-price shoes, and when new season shoes average around £120-150 you're still paying a lot for your uniform, when you earn such a pittance to begin with. Women must wear makeup, have preened nails, and nicely-styled hair, and heels are very much pressured and preferred - is this the 1950s? Uniforms within department store concessions have to be one of two styles of dresses (and you only get one actual dress, even if you work full time hours on a 9 hr contract!). Male employees can pretty much look however they want. You are expected to come in 15 minutes early every shift, but you are not paid for it, and you are given a formal warning if you do not. This daily 15 minutes adds up to literally days of free labour. I earned £2.50 an hour plus commission. I had to ask what happens if it's a quiet day, and their answer was "Don't worry, the system works it out so that you never get less than minimum wage." I never saw this in action, and of course I wasn't given access to records of all of my sales across each month, so I was never sure that this was actually true. The system to allocate commission is questionable: if the store is being shut by junior members of staff, they are responsible for entering everyone's sales into the system, and they could easily enter some in on their own name and never be caught out. It should always be entered by a neutral party (i.e. manager) who doesn't get commission. The behaviour of one manager was abusive, bullying and absolutely toxic, but she was moved to a different branch. Nothing was done and I believe she is still working there. The employees are not empowered to come forward to report bullying.

headline: Great culture but will take you 20 years to break out of middle management
pros:
Legal and general is like an old Bentley. comfy with a powerful engine, but a lot of weight to shift. It’ll be nice to be in, but 0-60 will take 20 years.

Big org, diverse environments to work in. Wonderful people and changeable pace, lots of best practice to learn from. It’s highly regulated, so you see what good looks like every day.

I enjoyed all the teams I worked with. Loved the different divisions and completely different operating models. I worked in many locations. Kingswood, Cardiff, Brighton, London and even regional partners.

I started as a Senior Finance Analyst and progressed to management fairly fast in 2 years. Being a business partner to multiple divisions across a few entities has given me some great insights into operating models, having some challenging projects to work on commercially and financially.

It’s hard to make a difference there; to have a voice and face. I managed to, but had to slog and really push change to sell it more widely. Shouldn’t be so hard to make things better.
cons:
In finance it’s hard to get up the chain into senior leadership there and regardless of skills, shining reviews, outstanding performance etc, restructures set people back year in year out, which is pretty awful; there’s a lot of competition from Group finance who are markedly more visible to leadership, so opportunities there is fairly static and staid. You just have to see how long people stay “finance managers” before becoming heads. Some 10 years, (reshuffled, relearn, reestablish, outperform, only to be displaced due to restructure to start all over again). When that happens to the superstars, you know there are issues. 

It’s poorly paid as well. For a FTSE it’s shocking. It’s not until you leave that you realise how bad the pay grades are. Pigeonholed in Finance, in middle management, during the most important time of your career to diversify and grow.

I left, took a seniority cut in different sector, (a charity at that) earning £10,000k more + 20% bonus, was promoted in new role within 6 months. Within a year promoted again as a head in FP&A and Business Improvements. So after pouring heart and soul into that company, to earn peanuts for 7 years at L&G as a high performing Finance Manager, within 4 years of leaving, 2 companies later, I’m now an Operations Director, with loads more experience and on track for a fulfilling career doing what I do best.

I interviewed at legal and general a couple years back in Hove. Unsurprisingly it seemed the world had stopped going back there. Even the tech and ways of working were the same. (Which filled me with dread given how much the world had advanced with MS Teams/interview techniques/tablets etc) I realised it’s a leviathan and will take tens of years to change process and senior leadership. It’s stifling. Systems are still same, ways of working are backward and unsurprisingly, I found myself questioning why I’d want to work there again after tasting what “excellent” looks and feels like.

Quite stark. That industry really grabs a person and pins them in place.

Training opportunities and courses are archaic too.

headline: Making so many customers lives better every day
pros:
You'd be incredibly surprised about the breadth of L&G - we touch the financial products that all of us need throughout all of our lives: from Life Insurance to later life living, from Pensions, through to ISAs, Lifetime Mortgages & our Care propositions. And we focus on making it easier, better & more accessible to our customers in every way that we can. Everyone really cares here.

Plus L&G also invests in really entrepreneurial & ethical new areas like Affordable Homes & our underpinning Inclusive Capitalism overarching purpose that allows us to invest in the evolution of our cities and our environmentally friendly future.

It's a big company that can do incredible amounts of good, but it also feels small, authentic & manageable. It has a wide variety of roles, from customer facing, regulator facing, through to digital, engineering, actuarial roles, customer service & financial services SMEs. Our Digital Teams here have grown exponentially over the years and will only continue to get bigger and better.

Women and men excel alike. There are many women in top roles & it's never felt unbalanced here at L&G. Indeed annual reviews of pay scales take place unprompted to ensure equality continues to be a top priority. Location-wise we're dotted across many lovely places across the UK too, so it provides variety in where you can base yourself.
cons: We are a company on a big journey with a strong mission but it can, like in all large organisations, take a while to get there. We're not as nimble as the start-ups and do have the expected amount of legacy tech behind us, but that's because we're a company that's been doing business for a long time. That said, there are many plans in place to allow us to both catch up & move ahead - we all play our role in creating that future.

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Pay is decent except no overtime rate.
cons:
So firstly they lied to most people who joined within the first year of the RDC opening during interviews as they told most of us things like we would be working 1 weekend in 4 (you actually work 3 weekends in 4). We were told we get a £1 a year pay rise and we are currently getting 40p a year which is now capped after 3 years at £10.50 (new starters reach £10.50 in a year now). We were told we get lots of benefits like cheaper contracts with EE and cinema tickets which was a lie.

The place is also run by senior managers who want nothing to do with warehouse staff and care only about productivity and not staff health or wellbeing. Below them are the ATMs who are so stressed due to senior management that they often take it out on warehouse staff and charge hands. The charge hands (which no longer even get £1 extra an hour) are dropping like flies and stepping down so quickly that they are forced to continue to do the charge hand role and are on the verge of mental break downs until they can convince some gullible sap to replace them and be a whipping boy for managers for no extra pay.

HR and recruitment are always scratching their heads and asking how they can improve the absolutely shocking staff turnover they have but don't seem to notice that the warehouse management seem to like the staff turnover as it is easier to convince new starters to work stupidly quick to achieve non existent progression. 

Injured at work and not your fault? Better hope you have sick days left because they aren't going to pay you and you'll need to get a union or solicitor involved to put in a claim to recoup lost wages. Also they have a tendency to lie to the council to make any accident seem like your fault to avoid guilt and then make you chase your own tail for cctv footage.

The rota patterns are terrible and always have been. Old pattern involved us working 7 days in a row sometimes with only one day off. Now we have working weeks of 5 days in, 1 day off, 4 days in, 1 day off f then another 5 days in. It kills you! And they still expect you to maintain a high performance target! 

Performing well or quickly means nothing to these people. You work harder they raise your targets. Meet those targets and they raise them again and will keep raising them until you can't achieve their targets then they will threaten you with disciplinary actions to push you to kill yourself attempting to hit their target or it pushes you to leave. You also won't get anywhere in the company by working harder as it seems to be if your face fits and not performance. Slow lazy people get easier jobs so they don't hurt their performance figures and certain people regardless of performance barely have to do any work. 

If you want to work here be prepared to be transported back to your schools days of being told of by your headmaster as that's how they treat you. Like a child.

headline: ok for a student job
pros: good pay, variety in tasks

Productivity is placed above the people. I had a pregnant co-worker who was refused reasonable adjustments to working conditions (she wanted light duties, but still had to do bakes and lift heavy things). 

It's impossible to meet the speed standards without breaking food and working safety rules. The chill chain is 20 minutes. So a chiller pallet needs to be worked in 20 minutes. This takes two employees, and both need to be fast. Usually, its not possible to arrange two fast employees on chiller every time. Usually it was me alone. Sometimes it was me and a slow employee. Only rarely did we have two fast workers on chiller. So the chill chain simply had to be broken most of the time chiller pallets were worked.

They drill it into you to be careful with alcohol sales, especially after a failed test purchase. AND at the same time, they'll mock you for being too careful.

There were loose blades in non-food, which was unsafe for both customers and employees.

headline: Absolute Shambles of a company
pros:
Allowed to work from home
Absolutely nothing else
Nice building in a nice location I suppose
cons:
No training
Poor management
Terrible culture

Nobody can do their job properly as no proper training is provided to anybody. 

You are bombarded with work as soon as you start the job, not given any chance to learn the ropes. 

I read all the bad reviews before accepting the job and put it down to people only writing a review if they’ve had a bad experience. Now I know the reviews were a true reflection of what it’s like here. I’ve spoken to people who have worked here a long time and nobody has a good word to say.

They also promise they’re going to put you through the IOC course and give you a pay rise when you complete it. It’s a scam, nobody has this qualification here. I think they just put it in the adverts to make you think the job might have prospects.

There is a culture of incompetence at the company. Other colleagues when asked for help, either ignore you or are unhelpful. I honestly think it’s because nobody is very good at the job due to lack of training.

Workloads are crazy as every department appears to be understaffed. Instead of getting more people in, they’ll just keep allocating you work that they know you won’t even be able to do for a month because your workload is so high.

headline: Worst job in the history of all jobs in my life
pros: Easy job, a monkey could do this job and most of the people there are.
cons:
Unfortunately nothing I have to say is good let's start with the fact that it is very clique, People are more interested in gossip and stories than the actual work itself.
Since being there I had noticed that although the motto is diversity and inclusion, for the most part if you had different opinions from the people that had been there a while they would not accept you into their group and would actively seek to try and get people fired.
The management leaves a lot to be desired as they too seem to have their favourites and would rather give into office politics and gossip leaving aside the quality of work.
I have yet to find a place where you could feel less job security than here fearing what someone may say behind your back with your job on the line, with all the immaturity of a primary school.
The job left me with severe anxiety and depression which is a shame as I had high hopes for such a reputable company. Alas this is just another call center job with a call center mentality with almost everyone having their moments of power tripping from the floor walkers to the so called specialists and team leaders.
A word of advice for anyone stepping foot into this establishment ... Don't! But if you must, just keep your head down and be the robot they want you to be.

cons: Very structured and bureacratic. A very big organisation in which it is difficult to get things done. Stong emphasis on project teams and contractors who leave those behind with quite a lot of clearing up to do. Systems and organisation is STILL split between heritage BOS and heritage Lloyds. 12 years on! Ring Fenced bank and Non Ring Fenced Bank structures, further complicate decision making. Bank is moving a lot of functions out of London, especially to Birmingham and Edinburgh. Function are very siloed and have been deskilled, so that junior employees do not have a particularly wide ranging experience. High turnover of staff in certain functions. Low levels of remedial IT investment in non retail, non sexy, client facing areas.

headline: Watered down talent
pros:
I love working here. The intellectual challenge, the impact, and the access is second to none.

It has been a tough ride to get to AP for me (political, luck, etc) - but the headwind made me improve myself and I am now genuinely happy for the person I've become

WLB is up to you once you become EM+. I honestly worked at max 10 hours a day, each day, since I got designated EM. If someone is EM+ and still struggling with WLB, it is honestly them (and not the company) that is at fault

"Make your own McKinsey". It is true. You can literally choose to create your own path // create new assets// create new clients or whitespace. I just love that.
cons:
Being watered down over the last 3-5 years

1. Digital - yes, it is the future of life. However there is more to running a business than Digital. That "human" component is being watered down

2. Talent - McKinsey doesnt care about IQ anymore. In the name of MI, Digital and other pursuits it is chasing experts who don't have the same intellectual bandwidth of a traditional McK generalist. 

I am not dismissing experts. I am just dismissive of the experts that McKinsey hires. Why cant we find experts who actually can hold a candle to generalists? I don't know.

headline: An okay place to build some skills
pros:
This is within Mercer's Health and Benefits Consulting group. It's a decent place to start after graduation. Base pay can be pretty low, especially if you're not on the actuarial track and are a strategy consultant. However, pay is hourly and you are compensated for the long overtime you have to work, evening out pay to a decent living wage (pre-pandemic, during COVID OT was cut for all junior employees, yet middle management and senior leadership saw no pay cuts, pushing analysts to not be able to afford to live in NYC and not get compensated for work they did, but I digress)

People are friendly, and it's a great learning opportunity. If you are lucky to get put under the right teams and people, your responsibilities can grow very quickly and you can get exposed to a lot.
cons:
The pay discrepancy between consultants on the actuarial track vs strategy is absurd, especially at the lower levels where the difference in responsibilities is actually minimal. Actuarial consultants also have near unlimited budgets for employee development for their tests, while generalists do not have the same opportunities to earn even relevant certifications on the company's dime. This is why attrition is so high on the general strategy consultants side.

Also, with the exception of very senior principal/partner levels, promotions are based almost exclusively on tenure rather than performance, alienating higher performers when consistently low performers get promoted along with them.

Also for a health benefits brokerage firm, the benefits packages are ironically pretty terrible.

headline: Avoid like the plague!
pros:
Some nice people to work with
Good pension scheme
cons:
The culture is really not what it used to be.
Since the new management took over, it has all gone downhill.
Extremely long hours, no work life balance, senior managers and directors email and message at all hours (earliest I got was 5am and latest midnight), even though they claim that ‘they are happy to discuss flexible working’. Flexible meaning, you have to be flexible and around.
Career progression is based on favouritism, or knowing that if they don’t promote, people will definitely leave, and people agreeing to get promotions without a raise with a semi-promise that they will get something the next year. Don’t ask for a raise, you won’t get it and you will end up 
 in their bad books.
The pay is low, the benefits are not great, except for the pension which is pretty good.
Don’t expect bonuses to be of much worth, and they stress that they are discretionary.
They don’t actually care about well-being, people being overworked and underpaid. It’s extremely difficult to get in lieu time for the extra time worked even if your manager knows that you have worked 10-12 hour days.
If you do decide to join, treat this as a temporary gig, most people leave after a couple of years, primarily the ones who are good at their jobs. The rest get promoted to fill roles that are incapable of doing.
Also, forget about training, there is literally no budget for that. They have an internal team who (bless them) do the best they can, but clearly are not going to be able to offer specialised training in areas outside the core bank roles.
Don’t make the same mistake I made to buy into the ‘culture’, it’s at best a facade. Who is left is some senior directors who have no clue what they are doing and destroying anything good left from the culture.

headline: Worst place I’ve ever worked
pros: Non management colleagues are a credit to the company. Promised so much and rarely receive anything. I feel so sorry for what they have been told in terms of progression and development as this is just a myth and they only find out a few weeks into their role. “Your promotion path is endless” colleagues get told.
cons:
- Never have I worked in a company where money is just thrown at the most irrelevant causes. It is shocking to think how much money Metro have thrown away that shareholders are unaware of
- Promotions only occur if you have the gift of the gab in terms of sucking up. Forget being rewarded for hard work and initiative - you will only be promoted if you agree with management and never ever challenge the norm. Metro prides itself on apparently listening to everyone - trust me this does not happen. You could flag risks until you are blue in the face but nothing will happen
- HR department have made up promotions that they give to their staff to give them higher titles. These roles are never advertised or earnt, they are simply given so when these colleagues leave Metro they stand a better chance of obtaining a higher position outside of the bank. I feel sorry for other companies that hire anyone from Metro as they will think they are doing say a Head of role when the functions they are doing don't even warrant that of a manager. Someone had 4 promotions in 1 year to become a director - think that says it all.
- There are meetings galore without anything ever coming from it. All people do at Metro bank is talk without ever completing anything. All political spin jargon to make everything sound professional but in reality it is shocking how unprofessional the company is.
- You will not believe how many made up titles Metro have which means there are about 10 people doing the same job as you and you end up constantly challenging other people as to why they are doing what you should be doing.

In some parts a very forward thing company I.e technology

Social responsibility is non existent when it comes to ethnic minorities. The company’s leadership team at every turn, challenge and opportunity have a shocking appetitive to getting things wrong or just being complicit. 

If fully reflects Britain as it is in the sense that it is the least meritocratic company I’ve ever worked for but it continues to spit out garbage about opportunities. This is evident especially at the higher levels so from level 3 and above, I mean I personally know regional managers vacancies that where advertised but filled after the director personally rang someone to offer them a job without even going through the interview process (nepotism) 

Crabs in the barrel mentality is encouraged immensely by deliberately putting people against each other and not in a healthy competitive manner but almost for sport 

Leadership team aren’t leaders, they are simply managers who micro manage at every stage. They don’t inspire or lead. They don’t trust their colleagues or employees to deliver even though they are the ones that will deliver kpis and objectives.

Lastly, as a leader myself i would sacrifice my interests for the benefit of my team. In Morrison’s almost every leader from store manager level upwards would and in cases were I’ve personally experience sacrifice their colleagues for their own interest and gains

headline: Not worth it
pros:
I enjoyed the steady pay increase. I started on £8.20 and left on £10 phr which I was happy about. The covid bonus was a great idea and appreciated. 

You receive three discount cards when you start.

I made a few really great friends
cons:
Ironically HR were NOT people persons. Many of us were extremely intimidated by them. One minute they were happy and the next unhappy. Very unapproachable.

The work culture was toxic. Team leaders in the home delivery department just gossiped about the managers, how lazy the other team leaders were and gossiped about the pickers too. They dont understand confidentiality, hence private matters are known all around the store due to the gossipy work culture. 

A common theme was how they hated the job and were all looking to move on. They arrive on shift in a foul mood, and vocally state they don't care about the department and are looking for other jobs. Blame pickers for everything that goes wrong, even when they are the ones 'leading' us. Great for morale.

Terrible team leaders who were promoted for no other reason than the other leaders quit. They're given greater responsibility without any training, they don't know what leading is and love to micromanage. Many of them lack people skills and lack organisation. Hence the reason they demote themselves to picker because the role doesn't suit them, then ask to be a leader again because they want the pay. Made pickers do their jobs then wonder why the pickers fall behind.

They tell you off for talking even if it's about work, then you go into the warehouse and theyre having a gossip about their dating lives/clubbing. 

You tell the manager your availability and then they go on to ignore it. Always got phone calls telling me to come into work on my days off, then told it was an expectation.

The communication was NONEXISTENT. Store manager told me the manager meetings happen on the shop floor. Lol. It felt like most days I turned up on shift, I would get told off for something that was perceived fine the week before... This was because all procedures, rule changes and messages, were communicated in passing. Rather than by company emails.

4 home delivery managers in 10 months... It was a mess
