headline: Get out now whilst you still can!!
pros: Absolutely none whatsoever! If i could give 0 stars i would.
cons:
Firstly, let me start off by saying if you have just started at Northern Gas and Power Run! Get out now whilst you still can! This job will suck your soul and drain any life and enthusiasm you had to begin with, leaving you an empty shell of a human being and a shadow of your former self.

Let’s drop a few truth bombs, in training you are sold the dream. They spend a whole day telling you how much money you are going to make and whatever your hopes and dreams are, write them down because you will achieve them all whilst working here with the cringe worthy phrase "one call can change your life" this saying is designed to give you hope, but you will quickly learn that you've got more chance of finding a well in the Sahara Desert and any hope you do have in this job will be ended quicker than Usain Bolt running the 100m.

The reality is you are working in a bottom of the barrel call centre making between 150-200 calls a day to businesses that have been called by NGP every day, sometimes up to 6 times a day! I have literally had people pick up the phone and say "Hello Northern, Gas and Power" before I’ve even said a word! Hammered is an understatement. These people don't want to speak to you and you have to ring them to achieve the minimum 3hrs talk time per day. Bearing in mind the average time on one call is about 1 minute you can see how your day pans out! I can’t tell you how many times management repeat the saying "3 hours or sale!" yep I think I got that, you tell me that about 12 times a day! Towards the end of the day you are just doing call time for call time’s sake anyway.

In regards to making loads of money, you will start off as a lead generator and any "deal" you get has to be split with a closer 50/50. In order to pass your probation and start earning commission you need to make £30,000 for the company in 3 months. Now bearing in mind you have to split any sale you get with your closer, therefore you have to make £60,000 in 3 months in order to pass probation. Do you know how much commission you will make if you achieve this target in 3 months? Based on the commission structure you will receive £300!! That's right £300. So I make the company £60,000 and the reward I get is £300? I've seen better prizes at Gala Bingo on a Wednesday. 

They say closers will close 70% of the "deals" you give them, in my experience its more around the region of 15%. They are only ever interested in their own deals and will get around to yours if they can be bothered. You have to constantly ask them what's happening with your "deals" and most of the time they don't even know what "deal" you’re talking about! I have referred to "deals" in this review in inverted commas this is because NEVER get excited by a "deal", they will never get closed and if they do, a couple of days later you can bet that they will fall into objection. How are you supposed to put money on your board if your closers are incompetent?

Don't even get me started on the ticket system! Once you have bills and an LOA you need to submit a ticket so that you can obtain the information you need. I am convinced the ticket system is like a black hole. You send the information into the hole and it just disappears and no-one really knows where it ends up! I submitted a few tickets and no word of a lie just over 1 month later they replied "do you still need this?" It’s been a month! what do you think?! The people that work there are utterly useless and I really don't know what they do all day! 

The people in the "office" (call centre) you work in, truly believe their job is like 'The Wolf of Wall Street'. They come in dressed in 3 piece suits to sit on the phones all day! They start the day with this pointless and embarrassing desk bang where for 2mins you just bang your desk continuously. It’s supposed to get you all revved up for the day but in actual fact it leaves you cringing and makes your hands hurt! You are also told constantly to stand up whilst make calls to get some atmosphere in the place, but trying to create atmosphere in there is like trying to relight a burnt match!

On the topic of being pointless, there are 4 meetings a day and each meeting, they say exactly the same thing word for word! They would be better off just recording one meeting and playing it after each break on a tape recorder - it’s that repetitive! 

The whole "office" is kept in sub-zero temperatures it should actually be considered a slow form of torture, even eskimos would struggle! their reasoning behind the temperature is that "It keeps you alert" but it’s hard to be alert when I can’t feel my fingers and toes and my heart rate has dropped to an alarmingly slow rate!

To conclude, this is the WORST job I have ever had in my entire life, there have been several occasions when I have gone to the toilet and looked for suitable places to end it all. The people are terrible, the money is terrible, the "office" is terrible the company and the job are both terrible. Don’t do it to yourselves!! trust me you will be much better off. This was a painful harrowing experience and I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy! I can’t tell you the happiness that washes over me knowing that I never have to set foot in that place again. I still get PTSD from trigger words such as "3 hours" or "energy" but I can confidently say I am on the road to recovery and am thinking about starting a support group for those affected by Northern Gas and Power. What a terrible company to work for Sayonara suckers good luck hitting call time!

(Oh and if you’re wondering why this company has so many positive reviews, it’s because we are paid £10 to leave a positive review. When I was working there I did it because let’s face it a tenner is a tenner but don’t be fooled!)

headline: Fantastic place to work and grow, IF on the right team
pros:
I was lucky with the team I was assigned. I inherited a codebase in much need of some TLC but was given the opportunity to fix and rewrite where needed. I was very fortunate that I had a development manager who understood the importance of reducing tech debt. The office politics was at a minimum, my team was free to chose the right tech for the right job and we had the ability to explore new solutions and innovate where necessary. I actually felt like a tech lead rather than a dev with the title of tech lead who is bound by restrictive processes as I have experienced at other places.
Many opportunities for learning and development.
Some great tech challenges and I had a very supportive development manager.
Flexible working
No core hours
Flexi days
25 - 30 days holiday
Low stress environment.
cons:
I was lucky that I had a great product and a great team so I dont have any war stories but there is a major drawback to ONS:

As a developer; joining ONS is like playing Russian roulette with your career. You could be lucky (like I was) and get to use the latest cloud tech and explore new development practices as you see fit and work with forward thinking development/project managers. The other side to ONS is the old legacy side where you'll be stuck maintaining code that was written in languages that went unsupported more than 2 decades ago - imagine working on a codebase that was considered legacy before you were even born. Imagine a codebase so hopelessly broken and bloated that its almost impossible to refactor without simply burning the whole thing and starting again. Now imagine never being given the opportunity to improve that codebase or even being given the opportunity to move to another team. That's what awaits you if you get stuck with legacy. Career suicide.

I was fortunate that I never got stuck with legacy, my rating of ONS would be far lower if that was the case.

For any developer who is offered a position here, please check before you accept the offer - the team you will be working on, the product, tech and type of work you will be doing. Some of the developer positions are more like 1st line support. Don't fall for the line, "We have some old tech but we're hoping to upgrade soon". Remember, no upgrades after 20 years of legacy, you have to assume that their legacy system will still be there festering and ruining careers for another 20 years.

headline: Abandon all hope, ye who enter here
pros:
Decent money
Good range of problem domains (even if the solution domains are a bit restrictive)
Nobody ever says anything nasty to you, no matter what they think of you
Super positivity, if you like that kind of thing
cons:
It's a work cult.
Everyone at the company appears to believe they are doing amazing work.
Nobody at the company is doing the work required to do amazing work. There is never any analysis of failures or even admission of failures. There is never even any attempt to improve as there is never an admission of room to improve.
Everything is done at breakneck pace. Quality is sacrificed everywhere, but polish is never to be sacrificed.
You are sometimes asked for estimates, but in the vaguest possible terms. This estimate will come back to bite you, although you might not recognise it as your original estimate.
You are culturally forbidden from ever providing any negative feedback (like 'this can't be done in this time'). You must suck it all up yourself and work crazy hours to get stuff out the door. If you do not do this you will wonder why you are always getting rolled off projects and nothing you say matters -- negative feedback doesn't come your way either so you can never talk to anyone about why something didn't work (it's always assumed it's your fault) so nothing ever gets better.
If you do want to find out what really happened on a project you have to find someone willing to talk behind closed doors-- it's absolutely never done to talk openly about failure, everything is always an amazing breakthrough success.
If you want to survive at this company, learn to surf the very top of the Dunning-Kruger curve, because that's where you'll be the whole time.
And kiss goodbye to everything you do outside of work.

headline: Best company I've worked for, with a great corporate IT culture
pros:
Pearson was by far the best company I'd worked for, and were it not for COVID-19 changing life circumstances, I would still be there. I thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to work on hard problems with smart colleagues all over the world. I don't know if it's just the UK-driven corporate culture and all UK companies are like this, but this experience is something I will treasure for the rest of professional career.

Pros:
-Pay and benefits were at or above market rate for IT skills in the area
-Global footprint, a huge, diverse workforce and an inclusive culture
-Focus on talent development and maximizing team capabilities
-Collegial, collaborative atmosphere and decent managers and management
-Management actively solicits new ideas and is open to engaging, and does not have an authoritarian/top-down approach to 'performance culture' that many US-headquartered companies do
cons:
-Levels of bureaucracy and large organization mean decisions take a while to make
-Company will make investments in things without fully thinking through, only to discard later, when more thorough analysis could have saved time, money, and frustration

headline: Good work if you can get it
pros: PRH is the biggest publisher, so you take the good of massive size with the bad. For publishing, the entry level pay and benefits are good. Working from home during the pandemic was well-supported and the company never made us feel like we had to choose our jobs over our health. The big benefit for readers is access to the interior library of books and manuscripts.
cons: It's easy to get overlooked in such a big company, if you don't have a good supportive manager. There's a definite change in culture among management and upper management, who don't know or have forgotten what it is like to live in small apartments in the city while they tend to live outside the city - during the pandemic it seemed they weren't aware that while managers often had home offices, lower level employees would quite possibly have to work from atop their beds in studio apartments. The company is also overwhelmingly white and diversity initiatives move painfully slow, and company culture is quick to offer kudos for any small steps but hesitant to recognize missteps. Its also easy to feel left out of the loop if you don't like going for drinks.

headline: Ehh

cons: Get paid less than a dollar per delivery. Sometimes you only get 2 tips for a full shift. Only offers part-time with full time hours. Drivers do the most work at the store. Many customers were entitled and would lie to get free food or store credit. They would also blame you and yell at you if they made a mistake on their own online order. Not to mention, the Higher ups only care about speed and numbers. They don't care about you at all. Especially now during the pandemic. If they finally decide to close down a store near you for 2 weeks because of positive cases within that store, all the orders, including delivery, get sent to your store. You'll have to drive even further with no extra compensation. I say if because when there is a positive case within your store, they'll tell you to just keep working. They'll close it down when a couple of people test positive.

headline: Dreadful Communications and Poor Staff Management
pros:
The work is genuinely rewarding. 

The Service Users were occasionally challenging but usually great fun to be around. 

Most of the staff I worked with are lovely, caring and diligent people, and I hope to stay in contact with several of them. 

The grounds were (once upon a time) beautiful.
cons:
Management - the attitude of some individuals stinks (others were very supportive). 

Communications are abysmal - top-down, one-way and inefficient beyond nightmare status. Newsletters, clearly designed for online distribution, are printed out and circulated behind a signing sheet. None of the houses had computers or printers, so everything was done on paper, and if you ran out of any forms on the weekend you spent more time trying to scrounge forms from other houses than filling the damn things in. When they eventually find their way 'upstairs' they are typed in to a computer and then apparently forgotten about.

Investment is awful. The fabric of the building and grounds were very poorly maintained - there were innumerable safety issues that we had to live with, such as broken lighting, doors hanging off of hinges, damaged door locks and self-closers, and constant issues with laundry and cooking equipment. The grounds have been let go to wrack and ruin.

The food prepared for the service users is sometimes embarrassing. Crappy ingredients coupled with weird menus and bizarre recipes put together by people whose skill level ran from 'chef' standard to worse than '1st-year-at-Uni'. The site deals with eating disorders but I never met anyone with any form of qualification as a nutritionist or dietician.

Career and professional development is treated as a burden. If you find a course to expand upon a special interest don't even waste your time applying for support or funding.

The worst thing is that the site manager at my location couldn't be bothered to talk to staff. When she does she is often rude. When she visits the service users she is often rude to them and nearly always provokes some kind of incident for the Support Workers to manage after she's gone. And she seems totally oblivious to her purpose (to care for her service users) and her biggest business issue (attracting and retaining staff).

Like so many other places in care, Trust, Loyalty and Flexibility are one-way streets.

headline: Lots of work available but there are some issues
pros:
-Work is available to those who want the hours. 

-Flexible around commitments as many services operate 24/7.

-The work is challenging due to complex needs service users but at least each day is different. The friendly teams of staff you work with day in day out will make learning the job and also the long days easier. 

-They have one of the most extensive career development pathways in the industry if you are willing to pursue it.
cons:
-As with the wider privatised healthcare/adult care industry employee benefit/conditions have been reduced to the legal minimum.
No sick pay other than SSP, no rising with years of service annual leave, no hourly enhancements for Nightshift, weekends. or overtime. Some services give temporary uplifts for example £1 an hour in times of desperate need but this is rare. In the organisations defence it should be noted the reduced benefits is an industry wide problem directly resulting from post 2010 government spending cuts to NHS and Local Councils, as this is where most revenue comes from. 

-Linked to the first point, some long standing staff are on older contracts and have sick pay entitlement, rising holiday entitlement, and uplifts for Nightshifts, weekends and overtime. While I would never want them stripped of this It is important to note the effect it has on staff morale among the growing proportion of newer staff who do not have these benefits. In effect we are doing the exact same job for less.

headline: The nursing staff do their best with what they are given
pros: The empathetic people in the nursing team who really make the days bearable. Also, the lovely patients I get to work with who make my time there worthwhile.
cons: The divide between management and the nursing team is horrific. Complaints are not taken seriously, if a member of staff isn’t liked by senior management (which is often due to them standing up for their rights such as not wanting to work where they have previously been attacked) they will do their very best to push them out of the business. It seems a lot of the senior management have no empathy at all and treat the nursing team like annoying, demanding pests when all we really ask for is a bit of support, understanding and a higher number of staff on the wards so that we and the patients are not at risk of being injured. The wards are not safe because there are not enough staff to look after the patients that have such a high risk. I have worked countless shifts where patients have nearly died due to staff being rushed off their feet constantly and agency workers not being confident in a crisis.

headline: Life at REED
pros: The people is what makes the job what it is. Every single colleague that I work with is supportive and helpful. We have some excellent leaders steering the company and amazing programs to support career development such as mentoring schemes and Women in Leadership programs. REED also offers a variety of flexible working options which makes life a little easier when juggling a family too.
cons: I cannot think of anything negative to say.

headline: Brilliant company filled with brilliant people
pros:
First and foremost, the culture instilled from the top down is absolutely fantastic. It makes coming to work every day so much more enjoyable when you feel part of a great organisation and your work and your opinions are valued. It's a big family and everyone looks out for each other.

I work in sales - the bonus scheme is the best I've come across and even during the pandemic the business has found a way to reward and incentivize us through this really tough period in and out of lockdown

Outside of money, there are always extra awards, prizes, competitions and small gestures that personally make a big difference. 

We get an opportunity to give feedback every month and tell the Senior Leadership Team what we like and what we'd like to see improved. 

I hope to be at reed for many years to come.
cons:
From a sales point of view - it's a really tough market and it's becoming more crowded. I'd like to see more collaboration between Sales and Marketing so we can really drive improvement in site performance together. Hopefully it's something we can really focus on as we come out of the other side of this pandemic.

The Pension Scheme isn't brilliant (government minimum I think)

Micromanaging, upper management is very old fashioned, if you don’t suck up you won’t get far.

headline: Much more thanJu
pros:
Working for Randstad UK continues to be a journey that offers both personal and professional development opportunities that are exciting and varied via clear clear career pathways. Your career in firmly in your hands but is complimented by your manager and our L&D team.

The senior leadership team are connected to the wider business and truly demonstrate a commitment to the well being of employees. They drive clear and meaningful goals throughout our business and communicate frequently asking for our thoughts, feedback and encourage employees to have a voice and make a difference irrelevant of your experience, job title or how long you have been with the business. 

Randstad UK has a clear sales strategy, one which keeps our client needs at the forefront and opens the door to a wealth of solutions depended on the client needs not just what we offer locally. 

Not a word you would usually associate with recruitment but Randstad offer flexibility and have demonstrated the ability to adapt quickly and effectively to change. Which has led to positive outcomes for the business and our people where others in the sector have been challenged. 

The people. In the time I’ve worked at Randstad it has been refreshing to see that the drive and ambition that shows up in my team is replicated around the UK. Our people are determined and have a passion for the sector we are committed too. So if you have a desire to be the best you can be and be surrounded with like minded people, Randstad is the place you want to be.
cons: Prior to our exciting changes in 2021 our company felt siloed, it felt challenging to feel connected to other parts of the business. Already this has started to feel different barriers are being removed, our priorities are aligned and it makes working at Randstad a very exciting place to work!

headline: Great company that places its employees at the centre!
pros: A fantastic range of training and support is frequently provided to every member of the team. As someone who is completely new to the recruitment industry, I have felt fully supported in both my development and practices via the means of training seminars and peer support. Included within this, have been numerous 1:1 weekly support meetings with experts in the field. These meets have allowed me to share positive developments and areas to improve, to where my mentors have been yet again able to support me in bettering my professional practices. The teams I work with currently are a fantastic range of people, each stemming from different roles or backgrounds. They have truly made me feel included, supported and most importantly enjoy this role even more. Randstad as a whole, has an entire unity feel. Whether I need to discuss things with the branch manager, regional manager or even the CEO, I can contact anyone of these people in different positions of authority, and I know they will come back to me with a welcoming and supportive manor.
cons: There isn't anything I could really say about this company or my role in a negative way. However, if you are to join Randstad, I would recommend that your IT skills are up to date/efficient, as Administration plays a great role within a recruitment position.

Starting as a technician gave me an understanding of the industry that I needed to fully develop into a full National management roll. This alongside the brilliant training programs has given everything I need to progress even further into the business.

headline: No Work Life Balance and a fair bit of predjudice too!
pros:
- Fast training within a year of starting
- Mostly friendly people however theyre still very predjudice.
- You get to organise your own day.
- Get a company vehicle (might smell of rats)

I would just like to say that a lot of the older folks who'd been there years that I worked with were very happy with rentokil and it was mostly the younger and newer people who weren't very happy with it. The highest staff turnover was for young people too.
cons:
There are more cons than pros. 
There's a lot more than this too in more detailed areas. But I'll refrain from saying that here. 

- Grossly underpaid. A lot of other pest control companies do pay more as I had looked for other companies before deciding I never wanted to do pest control again.
- Horrendous staff retention meaning you will be constantly over worked and covering for people
- Only pay rise you will get is a potential bonus which you have to hit your KPIs to get. 
- Financial penalties and trackers if you don't hit KPIs
- People whove worked for the company for 20 years were on a salary of around £23k which is £3k more than the new graduate starters. The guy who trained me was only on £3k more than I was and he was IPAF trained, confined space trained, trained to use phosphine gas, could shoot and was a level 4 feild biologist level. 
- Sexist environment. A male dominated work place full of old men over the age of 50-60 who can be sexist and ageist. Its disgusting to work around. Very sexist attitude towards women who have children too and have to take time off work for their children. One of the team leaders was constantly critisized by her team and other staff for looking after her children. Team could be more diverse too. It just seemed a bit much. 
- If you do not feel safe doing something you can't just refuse to do it. They expect you do it even if it isn't safe to do - this pressure doesnt necessarily come from management more from your peers.  You have to learn to stand up and say no a lot to people rather than health and safety being just widely accepted. 
- Any greivances you raise at a team meeting will be brushed off. We had surveys done and over 50% of staff were unhappy. This was brushed off because people had 'filled in the survey and left' even though the survey was pretty recent. Really felt like we weren't listened to and there was no point in offering improvements. 
- expectation that your phone would be on outside of working hours. 
- Trying to write detailed reports on a mobile phone was difficult. You will probably end up with arthritis in your thumbs if you did this job for any length of time. 
- We were provided with tablets but you couldnt write your site reports on them so they were a bit redundant. 
- Mobile phones were often outdated and not fit to the task when a PDA would have been much better. 
- Mobile phones are used to track your movements.
- Problems could be difficult to solve as you would deal with a site manager or other employee rather than the person paying for the pest control meaning that it would take ages for the issue to get solved and there would be little penalty from rentokil if the client did not do as was advised which was very stressful.

This is my opinion from what I have seen and experienced and is anecdotal. As far as Im aware what I witnessed was true. Things may have changed since then. But I would not work for rentokil ever again because of my experience. I was only there a year too. I only did it for the work experience so I could do a job I actually wanted to do.

headline: Awful experience
pros: Really nice shop-floor colleagues, most are friendly and willing to teach retail newbies the ropes
cons:
Awful, horrendous, rude, egotistic and downright poor management. You're dropped on to the shop floor on your first shift and expected to know where all clothes are, where they're placed, how to return rejects from dressing room, how to handle the till, how to quickly tidy the floor of shoes. Managers will also bark orders at you through the walkie-talkie whilst you're still serving a customer, within earshot of them so they can hear how you're being spoken to.

If I could, I would rewind time and never accept the offer to join here as the money is just not worth the loss of sanity and absolute disrespect.

They say the customers are the rudest thing about retail but I actually dealt with really nice people and no one was rude to me - it was the disgusting management which were the rude ones and really need some house training.

If you want to spend your only life sitting at a desk and staring at a computer, this is the job for you!  The firm has a huge face time culture, despite them saying they don’t. Do not be deceived by the bonus structure, as you will likely get very little of it, if any,  as a new consultant. Certain teams seem to work longer then others. Would not recommend joining the severance tax practice, unless you can tolerate the “oil and gas” good old boys type.  The lack of diversity is ridiculous. Basically, you will be working on the wrong side, to save oil and gas clients money so they can continue to pollute the environment and contribute to climate change. I approved of the CEO until he decided to preach his conservative political views on a firm wide call. The work is very repetitive, requires no critical thinking, and is basically data entry, really does not even require a degree. Nonetheless, stay away unless you are desperate.

headline: A Disappointment
pros: The company's myRyan policies allow for flexibility. If you aren't familiar with what it is, myRyan is a system that allows you to work from home (even pre-pandemic) whenever you would like.
cons:
My experience at Ryan began with no training whatsoever. At first, I was fine with this because I felt prepared to do my job. But, my manager wanted things done in a particular way but would never communicate this forthrightly. Additionally, my manager was very absent and would only check in with me every few weeks or so. At first, this independence seemed like a good thing, since I am organized and kept track of all upcoming deadlines, etc. on my own. However, what I came to realize only too late is that my boss was very particular and fastidious; but, he would never explain to me what specific things he wanted done before I sent him my already finalized deliverable. (If you want something done a particular way, I certainly understand that; but if so, you must communicate that desire in advance.) In my whole time there, the longest email instructions I received from my manager were probably ~2 sentences long. That isn't hyperbole. How can you work successfully in such an opaque environment? In all my official WorkDay reviews I received thumbs up and heard that I was doing great. That happened at 2 months, 6 months, etc; then, at one year I was sent a surprise email outside of WorkDay basically saying I'm not meeting expectations, which set up the stage for me to be fired a couple weeks later -no notice, no further explanation. The way I was treated at Ryan was very unprofessional and I did not enjoy my experience. I say this not out of spite but because its my actual experience. I hope you find this truthfulness helpful. Read other reviews and I think you'll start to see a pattern....
The only good thing I say about my experience is that my co-workers were friendly, kind and always helpful. Management? the opposite.

The PPO is expensive and the out of pocket amount for one person is more than $2,500 a year which is a lot when the salary is already low. Depending on the team you are on, you may not have contact with anyone for weeks at a time besides submitting assignments. The work environment is busy and since you can work remotely and be busy all year, it can feel isolating. The starting salary even for individuals with graduate degrees are low. headline: Best Employer I've ever worked for
pros:
Career Opportunities & D&I - Focused on doing the right thing and ensuring everyone is regularly offered and takes advantage of mandatory trained on critical topics such as Security, Quality, Diversity and Inclusion. Provide access to multiple online and webinar trainings to develop their People.
Technology - a huge variety of tech' and a driving movement towards Cloud offering yet more opportunities from Salesforce, .Net, C#, Java, JS, Angular, REST, API's, Selenium etc.
Comp' & Benefits - tangible bonus system that you have control over a proportion of making personal responsibility a key attribute of their employees. This sparks people on to giving their best. I could go on for days.
Culture and Values - Satisfaction surveys where actions is promptly taken. Sensible 
Senior Management - Switched on, smart, capable and care about their people (not resources). Fully recognise the value we all bring and are appreciative at every opportunity. Covid - absolutely outstanding in caring for staff health and wellbeing, avoided Furlough, protected jobs, considerate of everyone's situation and been fantastic with comm's, updates, flexibility and resources such as free Mindfulness app.
Work/Life Balance - Incredibly supportive of this with flexible hours, open conversations on concerns in this area and help always available from managers to juggle the Covid new world we live in. Additionally (unprompted) offered 3 additional wellbeing days off on top of annual leave to spend on caring for ourselves so we bring our best selves to work every day.

I've worked for many employers from start-ups to blue chip and rarely do I wax lyrical about how good an employer is, as I have high standards. Sage has regularly exceeded these in my 4 years here.
cons: None that I can think of. Big company making big changes but somehow manage to have that small startup touch.

headline: Terrible working environment and management
pros: Some great people work there.
cons:
Customer service staff are worked and treated like robots ('robots' is putting it politely) to meet ridiculous sales targets despite not working in a sales role and being in the middle of a global pandemic. 
It feels embarrassing pushing sales of products that customers do not need onto them , when they have called in for help and are telling you how worried they are about their businesses in the current climate. 
The pressure placed is immense with no regard for staff mental health, whilst there are regular 'Your Voice' surveys sent around no change is ever made. The voices of those working with the customer service roles go unheard, when plucking up the courage to speak to management every struggle is dismissed and rather than being supported you are viewed as a problem.
There has been no effort made at all within the customer service job to make things any better for people during the WFH period.
Sage was a much better place when the focus was on actually helping the customer rather than sales, leave that to the sales team.

headline: Great part time job
pros:
I worked while I was a uni student and worked at a store very close to my university, which meant that during university holidays, the store was very quiet. This meant that I was not needed during the Christmas and Summer holiday periods which was incredible to find in a job.
You can work with really great people, I made a lot of friends here.
The business of each shift is pretty easy to judge depending on the day of the week it is.
cons:
I originally started as a Checkout Assistant but then became a Supervisor about a year into the job. There isn't any pay rise with this even though the amount of knowledge required, responsibility and pressure is a lot higher. This is because Supervisors don't technically exist in Sainsbury's anymore as everyone is meant to be trained to the same level, but nobody can be bothered to train everyone up that much and some people are not interested in having to learn so much.
On my last paycheck, they paid me £400 less than I was meant to receive, but they had locked me out of the HR centre where I would be able to view my paycheck as I was leaving. I was advised to call the HR department but they literally NEVER answer the phone. Only after a manager actually dealt with it did I get paid any more, but I was still paid £30 short. Getting hugely underpaid on your last month's paycheck is a really common issue, and Sainsbury's make it very difficult for you to chase up anyone about it. So just be prepped for that as it was a horrible note to leave on.

You are empowered over and over again to be successful - so if you aren't hitting or exceeding your number, it's not because of the patch, or the situation - it's because you aren't taking enough advantage of the enablement.
cons:
Sales is sales and with a resetting quota at the end of every month, you have to be prepared to reset at $0 and do it all over again. 
Even though we get 19 Days off in the first year, it's hard to take time off because the less you work, the less you make.
Company is growing from a startup to a major corporation - that growth means there are a lot of things that are changing and you hear about the "good old days" a lot - as if you missed out on how things used to be (not pre pandemic, I mean like 10 years ago) and things have changed a lot.

job_title: Senior Vice President Strategic Customer Advisor
headline: Amazing Culture
pros: A fast growing, innovative company. Full of smart, intelligent, caring people. Really lives the core values of "Trust, Customer Success, Innovation and Equality" in a way that I have never seen in any other company that I have worked for. I love the 1+1+1 philanthropy and way every employee embraces this. From the CEO down people liv the values, publicly express those values and passionately care for the customers success. It is a fun, exciting and vibrant place to work. You get swept along with the raw energy of working here. Senior managers walk the talk and this is learning culture, You work hard and play hard and have a lot of fun on the way. There are not many companies in the world who have a weekly all hands call that thousands tune in to, the CEO and leadership team attend, and nearly always has a major Hollywood, business or musical star as part of the event!
cons: At 20 years old and growing fast, you can see some growing pains. Lack of "big company" structure sometimes causes internal strife. Talking can overcome this, but it may require some more disciplined approaches in the future.

-No process to change role internally. The recruiter will lure you by saying you can switch internally but there is only politics here. Managers will not let you switch to development.
-I joined Salesforce as a Support Engineer recently and the experience has been not good. Managers are poor
- There are no holidays in Salesforce Support in Hyderabad. Manager can ask you to work even on 15th August or 26th January.
-I read many reviews where people write good salary as a con but you need to understand that it's a product based company so definitely it will offer more than service based companies. For me, the recruiter tricked me into received less package compared to others.
-Salesforce says there is Ohana culture but the Hyderabad office is pathetic. You can't expect Ohana culture wherever there are Indians.
-Managers are unprofessional, they don't let you take advantage of the benefits offered by Salesforce as if it's their own money.

headline: Horrible Management
pros: Decent Pay; Most of my coworkers were good people.
cons:
Serco in London, KY is by far the WORST managed company I have EVER worked for. They do not care at all about their employees. Management will stab you in the back just to get ahead. They show too much favoritism. I know several great employees who have quit because they refused to kiss management’s butt! And because they are an ‘at-will’ employer, they will fabricate stories to get rid of anyone that they cannot manipulate. I have seen it happen too many times!

They have been known on SEVERAL occasions to lay employees off, with absolutely NO notice! And, when they do rehire, they will hire new people instead of the ones who were laid off!

I have never worked for a company so unprofessional. They even rehired a guy who had been previously terminated for sexually harassing two different women. And, if that isn’t ridiculous enough, they had two managers who both had federal offenses against them.

On a positive note, though, for all you drug users, they don’t drug test. 😉

headline: 2.5 years not valued.
pros:
Free sky tv.
Good incentives.
Brilliant colleagues.
cons:
From the very beginning I knew that their mental health policies/show boating was purely superficial.
I advised an academy manager of my poor mental health and was advised that everyone felt that way and it was normal. 
Little to no support from a lot of the managers when it comes to mental health and if you try to take some time away you’re faced with absence hearings and “sanctions” which is enough to raise anyone’s anxiety.
I knew people in the Glasgow call centre that had been sanctioned because they were off following the loss of their parents... explain to me how that is promoting mental health awareness?
In the 2.5 years I worked there the bonus structure changed multiple times to the point we are now capped. I went from earning 800+ monthly to only being able to earn 620 maximum. Which was a massive change to my income especially during a pandemic when everyone is struggling.
I’m thankful to whoever went to the police and local government in regards to the response of the pandemic because they cared very little for the safety of their employees at the start of the pandemic. I can’t believe a company as large as sky did not have any form of contingency plan if we were required to work from home.

They *promote* people who are 6 months into the job that are clueless to raise the next batch of agents to show what a brilliant opportunity sky is and that you will progress. 

The reality is that people in there that are genuinely fantastic at their job are over looked for years on end. It gets to the point that most stop applying for role model or SIM because it’s too disheartening to be rejected again because someone with the right face has came along.

Also sending bullies to work for other areas of the business because they get reported is not helping and only dissuades people from reporting power hungry managers and bullies. 

It’s a shame because some of the managers are genuinely amazing. If it wasn’t for my previous manager I would have left less than a year into the role.

The final nail in the coffin was when I was off for a period of time struggling with grief and depression when I requested a Occ Health app to discuss options for change in hours/less strict stats I was told occ health would not be able to do anything for me.

Also on my final day my new manager didn’t bother to show me out the building and hasn’t bothered to contact me since to apologise or thank me for my time. I was a hard worker and my sales were fantastic. I deserved better.

Their able-bodied staff are left scrambling to do three times the workload they should be trying to carry and when you inevitably fail your boss will make unprofessional threats that would be violent if they weren't laughable. The "training" consists of them waking you up in the wee hours of the morning so they can spout off platitudes about their leftwing political ideology, feed you the most boring meal you've ever had, followed by some seminar that might've actually had some interesting info if I wasn't so tired and fed up that I just walked out. After my fourth shift I quit by text at midnight

The only reason you should take a job here is if a) you can pass yourself off as not speaking English or not being a capable of working so you can milk their payroll or b) so you can secretly record their incompetence and look for an excuse to sue them. God knows I wish I had done that second one myself. Other then that, avoid this dumpster fire like the cancer it is

cons: Specsavers stores are franchises so work environment can be very different. I've worked in a branch that was so awful and toxic. Store partners encouraged gossiping, enabled unprofessional behaviour, and were underpaying staff. In addition, the partners only cared about making money and would understaff the shop floor on purpose to make it more "fun" for everyone.

headline: Shambles
pros:
Worked with some great other colleagues
Some very capable and fair people in middle management
cons:
Many if not all of the problems here stem from a set of directors who seem to be completely oblivious as to how their staff feel. In my time at Specsavers, I saw petty, personal reactions from them in response to quite innocuous behaviour from staff, or scathing replies to genuine concerns raised by hardworking team members, who would go above and beyond whilst being short staffed and overworked, to ensure customers had the best experience possible.

Never, in any job I have had, has the disparity between work level and wage been so stark. The bonus scheme that was once in place, made it a little easier to make ends meet, but they rolled that back to a paltry £25 a week, which would only be paid if an increasingly challenging target was met. Both Grimsby and Cleethorpes stores are understaffed, when this issue has been raised one director in particular outright shot it down and even belittled staff for bringing it up. What he seemingly fails to have taken into account is that staff aren't simply serving customers, but answering a constantly ringing phone, booking appointments, chasing up jobs from other days, general housekeeping and so on and so forth. 

This doesn't surprise me, as his detachment from the shop floor and the feelings and morale of the staff has become a bit of a running joke, so dire is the situation. In a couple of instances, there are some very inept people in management also, who's only role seems to be to delegate to others whilst trying to look busy. Management is a mixed bag though, as there are at least 3 people within those stores who do a phenomenal job and are loved and respected by the staff.

They only take on new staff through the apprentice scheme as some sort of money saving tactic, rather than more experienced people, which only exacerbates the issues the existing staff have. Why anyone would be attracted to that apprenticeship scheme is beyond me, as the money is a poverty wage and there's nothing at the end of it, other than a minimum wage job with Specsavers.

Some mornings we would have these farcical training sessions, where exhausted and fed up staff would be given Pritt Sticks and glitter and told to make pretty posters, and lectured about customer service from people who hadn't seen a shop floor in years. 

I have never worked in a place so roundly despised by staff, and whenever concerns are raised, the attitude seems to be "well if you don't like it, there's the door"

The door seems to be the option staff are increasingly looking to take.

I would strongly advise against anyone working at Specsavers Grimsby and Cleethorpes.

headline: Work in progress
pros:
Well resourced: internally as regards depth and breadth of research across geographies and asset classes. Well equipped even if dual-systems post merger create complexity. Also externally in terms of access to research providers. 
T&Cs have been watered down over the years but overall remain very good, plus a market-leading parental leave policy.
A good place to start out in terms of a comprehensive graduate program, support for training such as CFA, and early professional responsibilities.
I have only ever witnessed good behaviour from colleagues across the business.
cons:
Almost four years since the merger of Standard Life and Aberdeen was announced it remains work-in-progress. In particular in terms of systems and also what has felt like repeated waves of restructurings across both the front-office and sales.
Business momentum has also been poor, and consequently remuneration has been very tough with pay close-to-frozen for a number of years. Repeated comments by very senior management since the merger that uncompetitive pay for juniors would be addressed has come to nothing. Also a lack of clarity for more senior team members as to what performance will result in better reward. 
A clear sense that the group is about to undergo further significant, and probably necessary, strategic change under the new CEO.

headline: £47k + for a sales exec is superb in this day and age... could be more focus on development and less micro-management.
pros:
Great pay structure, clear and concise commission structure - if you put in the effort with all the KPI’s you’ll be paid very well indeed.
Work every other weekend with a day off every week (average 5 day working week),also unheard of in motor industry these days, and extremely well received by all!!
Facilities are top notch. 
Everyone provided with a laptop, iPad and all equipment you can ask for to do your job properly. 

During Covid-19 this has meant ‘business as usual’ with C&C handovers and deliveries as staff have VPN access to be able to do their job at home fully. 
This leads onto stating that Sytner are a very pro-active company to work for - which does inspire confidence in the longevity of your job and the business.
cons:
Middle line management under a lot of pressure which can sometimes mean you don’t get the full amount of assistance required at key points as a Sales Exec.

The big concern of mine - people simply aren’t ‘promoted from within’ anywhere near enough as they should.

High performing individuals (and not to be big headed, but I would include myself in this category as I do work extremely hard in my job) just don’t seem to get picked when it comes down to a ‘final 3’ for a job.

It’s almost common practice now that if a Divisional Manager or recruitment ‘decision maker’ knows a ‘
friend or previous colleague who is at another dealer or dealer group, that has applied for a job, they automatically get it. 
It feels pointless applying for jobs within because of this.

If you are asked to apply - apply for the job
If you are not approached - don’t bother
That really is how it feels, and is how A LOT of colleagues are feeling at the moment.

headline: The place to be
pros:
Great people, great culture, great benefits.
After working for similar organisations in the past, I can safely say Access are different to others. Senior managers genuinely come across as if they care and their actions support this in every way. The effort that goes into Onboarding acquisitions and set them up for success is unparalleled. 
The company benefits including annual leave, holiday to spain (or extra leave), the drive for work:life balance, amongst many other show the culture is rewarding to anything willing to contribute to the wider course in the right way.
cons: Some may struggle with pace of change but the benefits from it are worth it

headline: Value your most precious resource
pros: Most people I work with are fantastic and very professional. The company is growing steadily and rapidly.
cons: There is a potential for great things in terms of product delivery and personal growth, but I am yet to see any of the 'promised land' on the horizon. Everyone got every ounce of their skill and energy squeezed out to the limit - at that point you either break and leave or you keep pushing through until you do. Oftentimes people are left feeling like a disposable resource 'if you can't take it anymore, there will be another that will'. This is frustrating because most people that get hired are actually great at what they do - hiring great people is only half the task, you need to nourish them and keep them.

headline: Good intentions - poor delivery
pros:
Access provide good pay and benefits and the company holiday incentive is great. They reward good performance well and generally treat staff with care and respect. 
They provide good training and have many good people working for them.
cons:
They acquire businesses they know nothing about & change everything to fit their model at the detriment of their customers and existing staff.
People are replaced with access staff and the development of the product slows down or stops - ruining businesses that thrived on being the “cutting edge” of their sector.
The access team aren’t bad people they just have their own ideas and don’t listen to experts within the businesses that they buy.

headline: Great way to start your professional career!
pros:
The Army gives you opportunities you'd be hard pressed to find in civilian life. At the age of 20 (if you join at 18) you could be earning adecent wage and have been payed well to become qualified in your chosen field. 
You will make mates that you will have for life and overall the the best thing about the Army is your peers. Once your trained the army will then give you the experience to go with your qualification, which is perfect for when you inevitably want to leave. Whilst new and keen, volunteer for as much stuff as possible. Courses, sports and Adventure training are all amazing things the Army offers so don't let them pass you by. The Army is as good as you make it. Be sociable and have pride in your work and the next 6-8 years will be great.
cons:
The reason I say enjoy the 6-8 years, is because that's how long it takes for the ridiculously outdated traditions and rules, along with the lack of communication between Higher ups who sit next to eachother.
When you first you essentially get told that if they are a higher rank than you then you do what they say because they have done more leadership courses/served more time than you have. Now even though these are valid points, from what I've seen more rank does not mean better leader, or that they have any form of leadership at all. This results in unintelligent power hungry Superiors who, if you stand up to the tyranny, will mess you about as much as possible. Guess what because the army pays you 24/7, means you can get messed about whenever they want. Had plans for the weekend? Doesn't matter, you stood up to a bully with 2 bananas so you don't deserve a weekend. 
A truly good Senior is hard to come by, because all the good people have the sense to leave. The rest are either a slave to the wage, or have been so indoctrinated that they can't adapt to civvie Street, so they treat others like they were treated and the cycle continues.
There Is only so much you can do. Doesn't matter if your great at your job, they will treat you like your just a number, because that is what you are.

headline: The worst job I've ever had
pros: None. Not even one good thing.
cons:
This is quite simply the worst job I've ever had. At first they paint a happy picture, telling you it's a family and coming across really nice, but it changes as soon as you start to work for them. 

Unless you work on the checkout, this job is hard work and they like to think you're a robot. A usual day working on a department includes working stock, being called to the till to sort issues out, and being bullied by management. You are expected to unload all the pallets of stock which are usually 6 to 7 feet tall with around 30 to 40 boxes of stock, sometimes we can have up to three of these. If you are on your own, you are expected to at least unload around two pallets of stock in a 6 hour shift and get them on the shelves as fast as possible. It isn't that simple though, you are called to the till numerous times during your shift to get items with barcodes or sort pricing issues out. Within your 6 hour shift, you are also expected to clean your department which can be a hard task when you are pushed to get stock out as quickly as possible. 

Management are bullies. At my store, there was a particular manager who was vile for no reason, and in my opinion, shouldn't be in a role such as the one she is in. I heard from numerous colleagues that she had driven people out of the company due to the way she talks to people. She doesn't treat anyone with respect but expects you to continue being subservient. Management also makes errors such as ones regarding hours. Sometimes you aren't given your contracted hours on your rota and if they find out you haven't worked your contracted hours, they blame you for it even though it is their fault for not rostering the right hours, it's also a challenge to chase them up about it as they just do not care.

Chances are you won't get paid properly either. When the minimum wages goes up, they don't pay you the new wage until a month after and then they dont give you the missing amount in the next payslip.

Colleagues are horrible and sly for no good reason and think they're above everyone because they've worked there longer. You also get the typical gossipers who will grass you out to the managers the first chance they get.

I left after just 7 weeks because in that time I had been bullied by management and it just generally wasn't good for my mental health
If you're thinking of working at The Range, don't. Avoid.

headline: Company culture has changed so much it's unrecognizable
pros:
Job security during the pandemic was never in question, we had constant reassurance from the CEO and other C-level execs that business is solid and there won't be any layoffs.

In general, this is a solid company to work for. There will always be work, so you'll never run out of things to do. There are frequent opportunities to develop laterally if that's your thing, you can learn new skills directly from the people who do that work for a living.

The pay is good for the industry and benefits are generous. We also got a $1000 WFH allowance to buy a desk/chair, a monitor, etc. The transition to WFH was seamlessand in general, management are attentive of work-life balance and will encourage you to take holiday if you need it.
cons:
We're moving away on all fronts from what made Unity unique and different from companies like Unreal. I remember when our mission was still to support small indie devs in bringing their vision to life. That's not the case anymore, it's all aggressive marketing over product quality.

Since we became a public company, every move internally and externally has been towards less transparency to users and internally and more corporate obstacles like more middle management and a centralized undemocratic environment.

Unity now makes it mandatory to install spyware and tracking applications on your work machines. Until last year, your machine was your machine and the company treated you like an adult capable of securing a laptop. They tried to roll this out without even notifying people at first, which directly went against our value of transparency.

Development is in chaos. We have far too many tech streams between the core editor and packages, releases can happen any time and you'll never know if a package released from another team will break the thing you're working on. Communication could be improved by a lot. If we had a vision it would be one thing, but right now we have a few different competing visions and that weaknes us overall.

Resources allocation is another problem for both human resources and teams funding. Critical systems are supported by tiny teams and non essential but flashy systems get most of the monye.

But the biggest disappointment to me, as a long time Unity employee, is how the company has started dealing with serious internal issues. Before, if you had a problem with someone, you could talk it out and resolve it and HR would help you mediate if necessary. Now, if something serious happens, like prolonged harrassment or abuse, we have an HR department whose only job is to protect the company and the abuser. Sure they tell you the spiel that they will talk to the abuser and coach him or her on how to be less toxic, but then the toxic behavior doesn't stop and subsequent complaints fall on deaf ears. They even try to discredit you or convince you that the problem lies with you, the complainant, and not with the person whose behavior is actually the problem. Gaslighting and isolating victims also supports this practice. How a company handles these unfrequent but serious incidents defines who that company wants to be. At this stage, Unity has failed some of its most vulnerable employees and that, more than anything, says a lot about how much gas changed.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
Some of the core values Unity tries to embrace are "Best Idea Wins", "Go Bold" and "In It Together". I've worked at many companies whose values are allegedly good, but don't actually take action on them. In contrast, Unity seems to really invest in these ideas. They deliver Active Listening training to leaders. They have a whole range of social events. They even have an entire Wellbeing team dedicated to running clubs and socials, sending gifts, and so on (so these responsibilities don't fall on the shoulders of people who are juggling this with other work)! They also have several Employee Resource Groups for people in marginalised groups (like a BIPOC one, an LGBTQ+ one, a women's ERG, and so on). Sustainability is also a core concern, with much discussion and events happening around that.

Every team is managed differently, so your experience may vary, but I am given lots of freedom to shape my job to fit myself, rather than change myself to fit the role. I can explore different technologies, collaborate across the organisation, and get involved in a wide variety of work.

The work is interesting and generously compensated (both in terms of salary and holiday allowance); the people are brilliantly smart, talented, and excellent listeners; and the technology is cutting-edge and exciting to work with. It's the most positive and inspirational workplace I've ever had the pleasure of working at.
cons:
Sometimes too many meetings, especially during the pandemic (as it's a big organisation).

If you're not from a corporate background, the jargon can be off-putting. There is a jargon glossary though!

Many different systems for different tasks. Not a huge problem, just a lot to learn when you first arrive.

Sometimes things are moving so fast, it feels as if we haven't finished one product/solution before we're working on or shipping the next one, which can damage credibility with users (e.g. if something ships with bugs)

headline: Life is like a box of chocolates...and so is Unity.
pros:
The Product, the CEO, and the vast majority of the people.

I've always believed that recruiting becomes much easier when you are passionate and knowledgeable about the product your company creates. Sprinkle in a customer service focus and point that toward your candidates and clients and you have the beginnings of a recipe for success. 

Add to that a great CEO; someone with a strong vision and someone you trust to do the right thing for the employees and (at least on the surface) you have the makings of a wonderful company.

As with most companies, at Unity, it's all about the team or the group you land within. Arguably, Unity has significantly more "good apples" than "bad apples" in terms of teams/groups so even the risk-averse should feel comfortable considering Unity.
cons:
Recruiting Leadership.

The culture that I was passionate about is being systematically removed by processes brought in a year ago by the new VP of Recruiting that force a focus on KPIs/metrics. While I agree that KPIs and/or metrics certainly have their place in a world that is all about numbers, "how" you use those numbers can make or break a recruiting organization.

In Unity's current model, hiring for culture fit becomes a secondary and oftentimes overlooked part of the equation because of the pressure to get hires. Much like trying to hire for inclusiveness, hiring for culture requires a deliberate approach, and if, as a recruiter, you need to decide between increasing your volume of hires to keep your job or focusing on making the "right" hires the choice is obvious. Invariably, over time, the original heart and soul of the company changes, or even worse, disappears. I specifically made the choice to leave Unity because the culture was becoming something I no longer recognized and related to.

Is Unity the right place for you? If you're a recruiter and you like to approach your job with the mentality of quality over quantity, Unity might not be the place for you. If you're a recruiter coming from an agency and you're looking for that first corporate opportunity that will act as a stepping stone, Unity will be very familiar to you.

The executive level leadership is transparent, honest, and humble. Despite recently IPO'ing, the leadership remains long-term focused, and employee focused. They are not cutting corners, cutting benefits, or reducing the level to which they listen to the company at large.
cons:
As we grow, we are slowly learning to be a larger company. Early on, Unity was entirely engineering driven. In that world, one- or two-engineer teams would spin up to solve problems. This led to a very agile and quick moving company, but we have somewhat out grown that. For one, our problems are often too big for just one or two engineers to hop-on then hop-off. Second, we have too many engineers to avoid repeat, overlapping, or conflicting work, if they all work on whatever pops up. 
Overall we are headed in a good direction. We are remaining engineering & bottoms-up driven, while building infrastructure to support larger teams, and larger communication efforts. The con here is that we're still learning how to do this. How many people are needed in roles like product or program management? How do large and disjoint teams divide up giant initiatives? And, how do we balance supporting legacy systems and developing new ones?

headline: Overall, a great interview and onboarding process!
pros:
My top three Pros:
1. Colleagues are all genuinely very nice and willing to help
2. Onboarding process is very organized
3. WFH and wellness allowances

I believe that when you're going through the interview process, not only is the company interviewing you, but you're also interviewing the company. From day one, the senior recruiter, Sarah Rideout, was amazing. My first touch point and I was sold! She notified me every step of the way, who I wold be meeting with next, what type of interview it would be, the duration of the interview -- all so that I could come prepared. I've never had an HR team be so welcoming and transparent! Really appreciated the process. 

Going through the onboarding process, it's the best one I've experienced to date. Keeping in mind, I joined the company during the pandemic and everything is done remotely. There's ample amount of ways you can self-educate, and everything is at your own place. If you are self-sufficient and a curious person, you will love the onboarding process. 

Last but not least, my team mates have been nothing but generous and kind. Everyone I've met to date is living and breathing Unity's values. It's refreshing to meet like-minded individuals that are all working towards common goals.
cons: I haven't ran into any yet, but I'm still fairly new so this could change!

headline: Usual exploitation of TA/RA on precarious contracts, not recommended
pros:
Can be interesting work depending of field.
Big variation of culture across schools, centre and departments.
This can be a pro or a con, depending where you stand.
cons:
For early career researchers: no security, tons of hours above coursework, absent PI.

In a way it's fairly preparing you for academic workplace conditions, that is if you're not tenured.

As all academic organisations, there are star PIs who focus on bringing large sums of money through research contracts to their schools or centre, meaning they offload their own workload to ECRs. 

Land in a cushy RA/TA post and your path is set, but land in a contested area of work/area of research and  be ready for precarity.

pros: The University of Leeds is a world-leading university for research. The union and student services are fantastic. Although the mental health services could do with being bigger and better funded (as they all do) the level of service from the counsellors is excellent. There is also active encouragement on a university and department level to identify what training would benefit you and depending on your funding source there's is an expectation to spend some of your assigned funding on external training as well as internal.
cons:
Experience doing a PhD will vary hugely depending on your research group and supervisors. For me I felt lacking support at times and ultimately left the position after 3 years as a result. I find some professors are significantly lacking in interpersonal skills and as such I felt unable to talk with them about some more personal sides to my PhD such as my mental health. 

The way the mental health services are set up meant at the time I was most struggling I was given a small number of sessions (with the possibility of entending if the counsellor felt it was necessary). After that you could refer again for more help. You definitely got the impression that counsellors were strectched thin and could only achieve so much with the resources they have. I felt a bit like putting a plaster over the problem each time and I had to go elsewhere for a more in-depth, lengthier treatment plan.

headline: Rewarding career in making positive changes to people lives, demotivating pay structure.
pros:
- Freedom, you have the responsibility to be in charge of committing your own time to build a diverse client portfolio, as well as having the freedom to create your own marketing and sales materials.

- Highly diverse and inclusive working culture.
cons:
- Tier pay scheme creates extreme seasonality and huge fluctuations in salaries. In the winter months, you can likely deliver in excess of 30 sessions a week at above £25. However, in the summer months, as families go abroad, you have no security and are likely to drop down a tier or two as your weekly sessions could possibly drop below 20. With huge fluctuations in salary, you can expect to be earning less than £20 per hour compared to £25 previously at no fault of your own.

- Limited scope for development. New PT's especially have limited support other than a workshop upon signing with Virgin Active. The companies focus is fixated on sales and fails to register or recognise the importance of personal branding and longevity.

- Sale orientated, management consistently judge your performance on the number of sessions you deliver a week or a month. Whilst sales are an important metric, management encourages PT's to offer additional sessions alongside the packages offered to clients to entice a purchase. This means for what we call a '4-pack', four sessions at a fixed price, we are encouraged to offer 5 or six, with the additional sessions coming off our own back, not the companies.

- Political, I can speak with experience and suggest this does not apply to all Virgin Active's, however, in-house politics can intensely affect the leads you are given as a PT. Management, once a month, used to give a list of new members so that we could cold call and see if they were interested in PT sessions. However, these lists were always given to the 'favourite' PT to begin with who would take over 50% of the leads whilst the remaining were segregated among the rest of us. We had eight PT's in our team.

headline: Toxic
pros:
Free gym membership
Great members & fun environment
Some really nice employees who didn't pay attention to the cliques
cons:
Poor pay - we were paid the personal trainer rate, which made no sense given that the PT team made extra money from their sessions. Only about $35k a year for full time, long hours & weekend work
High demand from employees - I had a surgery in my first couple of weeks & was told I would need to work the day after because it was so early on in my contract. I was so drugged up I eventually had to be sent home. There was also nobody who would cover my shift when my dog died so I spent the day on reception crying.
Difficult hours - 5:30am - 1:30pm, 11:00am - 7:00pm or 1:30pm - 9:30pm & weekends
Poor management - one of the managers really disliked me & when she moved into a higher position, performance managed me out, nit-picking & making it near impossible to perform well. I did do some things wrong that I learnt from, though it was awfully managed
Toxic culture - a lot of the trainers were blindly mean. One of the receptionists once bluntly stated the clique there had no bothered being friendly to me in the first 6 months because they were so used to people coming & going they didn't bother making new friendships until you'd been there 'long enough'
Impossible standards - the VA group had 5 values they asked everyone to stick by & unless you were EXACTLY this person, they didn't pay attention to you or encourage development
Awful member conditions - VA originally had a policy that if you wanted to suspend / freeze your membership, it had to be for 2 fortnightly debit cycles totalling 4 weeks. When members would question why they couldn't freeze for only 2 weeks, VA Head Office never provided a reasonable justification other than it was 'admin heavy'. There was zero justifiable reason to do it this way & resulted in a lot of frustrated members. Eventually they changed it to being able to suspend for only 2 weeks & it made the admin so much easier because people wouldn't have to cancel their suspensions when, for example, they returned from holidays & wanted to use the gym.

headline: A Disappointment & Career Dead-end
pros:
Permanent employees receive a ‘Privilege Card’ providing discounts across all restaurant brands, rooms are also discounted at Premier Inn – dependent upon local demand. Additionally, mattresses can be purchased at significant discount through the supply chain. 

There are two excellent restaurants on site at the Dunstable Support Centre, both managed by an external company. This is subsidised, although still a little pricey, but the staff are friendly and the food excellent. You can easily have your main meal for the day here every day of the week if you wish as there is plenty of variety.
cons:
Whitbread frequently misrepresent advertised roles to get job seekers through the front door. Unfortunately, I was told about their ‘reputation’ in this regard by a recruiter after I had left a great job to join Whitbread on the promise of opportunities for professional advancement. My role was not representative of what was advertised at all, which I later found to be a shared experience for the majority of my technical colleagues. 

Within IT the above is seemingly due to hiring managers not being technically aware. They frequently apply technical terms, but with an understanding which conflicts with those that are actual IT professionals. Managers generally lack any technical capability whatsoever and have achieved their position due to office cliques as opposed to experience or merit. Consequently, most techies leave within two years as it’s a constant uphill battle to get the most basic tasks completed. 

Those that don’t leave Whitbread IT out of frustration, management or antiquated process generally find themselves at risk of redundancy during one of the yearly restructures. Often these are the very same people hired to bring in their skills to help improve the state of IT as a whole. Worse still redundant roles have a tendency to re-appear on job boards weeks later with only the most minor of changes in job description. An indirect consequence of this is that the departments relationship with the current MSP is extremely toxic due a total lack of any continuity of ownership internally.

Providers are frequently blamed for these internal shortcomings openly within meetings in a rude an entirely unprofessional manner. They are also frequently used as a scapegoat by staff at all levels who are unwilling to take any personal accountability for poor state of IT services, which they are supposed to both manage and support. The behaviours demonstrated are truly contemptable, those that speak out or try to present a more balanced perspective are promptly bullied into submission or simply find themselves excluded from all conversations where they could really add value.

Sadly, I cannot recommend working here, as ‘The Whitbread Way’ (a term used by managers to say ‘that’s just how it is here’) will really disagree with IT professionals. Seeing a problem and envisaging a sound technical solution will be argued every single step of the way. The IT department is a real dead-end here, there is no scope to learn or grow whilst those in positions of power abuse it constantly whilst refusing to listen to those skilled workers who genuinely joined with a strong desire to improve products and services.

Managers bring in their friends to work, so creates a cronyistic atmosphere and personal biases. But, a well run location can be great all the same. So it's very much luck of the draw. headline: A legacy company in every sense
pros:
Premier Inn is a great product and a great brand and the people I've met in the hotels are brilliant. HQ in Dunstable is a very different story. There are *some* people trying to do the right thing, they are just up against a political culture and some very old fashioned thinking from an ageing leadership team.

In IT, the pay is generally pretty competitive considering it is based in the middle of nowhere and the discounts were good for staff. The coffee in head office is passable
cons:
Its an oversized, slow moving, risk adverse business. Everything costs millions (when it need not) and everything takes years. The senior executives are highly political with continual shake ups and people cut from the business left right and centre. The board has individuals who are from the nineties and the imported Tesco, burn-all-bridges career strategy cut means there are few team members safe any more.

In IT there is a dependency on a useless outsource partner that is unhealthy and so expensive it makes your eyes water but there is no action to improve things. There is a disjointed experience for those working in the swanky London office vs Dunstable and layers of management and bureaucracy are added to every piece of work making it such-hard-work to get things done. People still wear suits to work (although this was changing while I was there) and the attitude towards diversity is so poor that the unsaid joke about White-bread would be funny if it wasn't so painfully true.

headline: Top 🔝 Employer 2021
pros:
I have been in hospitality for most of my adult life and spent a career in different roles in the field around the UK and abroad and must say that Whitbread has been the best company to work with in all these years. Employees are individuals and treated not only fairly but also as top management would like themselves to be.

During the first lockdown not only did they top up furlough payments for all its team the company continually find moments of truth to better employee wellbeing.

I am proud 🥲 to work for Whitbread and now understand why some team have worked for the same company for 10-15 years. 
Take a bow top management and keep it up. 👍🏽
cons: None that I can honestly think of compared to other hospitality chains in the UK and trust me there is a stark difference.
